loans.name: Vilma Bartolomin

texts.es:
Vilma Bartolomin E. is the single mother of five. For more than 12 years she has supported her family with her weaving providing her children with food, shelter and schooling. In the face of competition from industrial weaving, Vilma has earned a reputation around Guatemala for her handwoven designs and the attention she shows her customers. In addition, she grows lettuce, tomatoes and carrots. She rises at 2:00 in the morning to sell her vegetables at the Terminal Market and upon returning home at 10:00 takes up her weaving.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Vilma Bartolomin E., lleva 12 años haciendo y vendiendo sus tejidos, donde su familia subsiste; es madre soltera, con 5 hijos; con éste trabajo ella mantiene a sus hijos, además les brinda estudio, alimentos y educación; pese a la gran competenia indsutrial en Guatemala, ella se ha caracterizado e identificado con sus clientes donde les da una atención personalizada e inmediata. Además ella siembra lo que es lechuga, zabahora, y tomate. Su actividad principal es la de los tejidos donde muchas personas de varios departamentos de Guatemala la conocen y la recomiendan por el trabajo hecho por sus manos; y la verdua ella la vende por mayor en el mercado de la Terminal de la zona 04 de Guatemala, se levanta a las 02:00 de la mañana para ir a venderlos, esta de regreso a su casa a las 10:00 de la mañana, donde des´pués de madrugar ella se dedica a la elaboración de sus tejidos.

loans.use: To buy yarn for weaving.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FAPE - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ni Putu Suantini

texts.id:
Ni Putu Suantini  tinggal di daerah pedesaan. Sebagai usaha yang dapat membantu pendapatan suami yaitu usaha beternak babi. Saat ini Ni Putu Suantini mempunyai 2 ekor induk 7 ekor penggemukkan dan 8 ekor bibit yang masih kecil-kecil.Untuk mencukupi pakan ternaknya Ni Putu Suantini membutuhkan biaya yang tidak sedikit apalagi harga pakan semakin mahal. Itulah yang menjadi kesulitan dalam usahanya.
Dengan menjadi Client Dinari, Ni Putu Suantini mendapat pinjaman dana dan pembinaan maupun penyuluhan mengenai ternaknya. Kebutuhan pakan ternaknya sudah dapat diatasi dengan ketersediaan pakan yang mudah bahkan sudah dibentuk depo pakan ternak di desanya. Untuk menambah jumlah ternaknya Ni Putu Suantini membeli satu induk  jenis Landrace. Kebersihkan kandang selalu dikerjakan setiap pagi dan sore hari. Penjualan dari bibit babi ini dilakukan setiap bulan dengan harapan ada pendapatan untuk keluarganya. Pendapatan bersih dalam setiap bulan dari hasil beternaknya dapat mencapai Rp.300.000,-.Usaha ini akan ditekuninya terus bahkan akan menambah jumlah induknya agar ketersediaan bibit  babi dalam setiap bulannya selalu tersedia.

loans.use: Membeli pakan ternak

loans.name: Suciastini

texts.id:
Suciantini lives with her husband and her infant child. As a newly-wed, for now she is living with her husband's parents. To help her driver husband in generating income, Suciantini raises, breeds and fattens pigs. She got her money to start the business from her husband's work as a driver and her parents’ in-law. Since the business is developing and creating enough profit, Suciantini would like to increase the number of her pigs with capital help from DINARI which will be used to buy 2 breeders, feed supply, and healthcare for her pigs. From one breeder which she has raised for 6 months, she can have 18 piggies sold for Rp. 4.500.00,- with net income for six months of Rp. 1.500.000,-. In the future she expects the increase of number of her breeder she raised will increase her income as well.

Translated from Indonesian by Iman Persada, Kiva volunteer.

Saat ini Suciastini tinggal bersama suaminya dan seorang anak yang masih balita. Karena baru saja membina rumah tangga, maka untuk saat ini tinggal bersama orang tua dari suaminya.Untuk menambah pendapatan suaminya yang bekerja sebagai sopir, Suciastini memelihara satu ekor induk dan satu ekor pengemukan. Modal awal yang dipergunakan untuk memulai usaha beternak babi ini adalah hasil jerih payah dari pekerjaan suaminya dan bantuan dari mertuanya. Karena semakin berkembang dan juga usaha ini mendatangkan keuntungan yang lumayan Suciastinipun ingin menambah jumlah babinya menjadi lebih banyak lagi dengan bantuan modal dari DINARI dipakai untuk membeli dua ekor induk babi dan juga untuk persediaan pakan dan kesehatan ternaknya. Dari satu ekor induk yang sudah dipeliharanya selama ini dalam 6 bulan menghasilkan 18 ekor bibit yang dijual dengan harga Rp.4.500.000,- dengan keuntungan bersih dalam enam bulan mencapai Rp1.500.0000,- harapan untuk kedepannya dengan bertambahnya jumlah induk babi yang dipelihara maka akan bertambah pula jumlah pendapatannya.

loans.use: To buy pig breeder

loans.name: Ni Made Wersih Krisi

texts.id:
Ni Made Wersih Kristiani has been raising pigs for quite some time. By buying few piggies and raise them for two or three months, she can generate good enough income. After joining and becoming Dinari’s client, Ni Made Wersih is planning to buy and raise a breeder to produce piggies so that she no longer has to buy them elsewhere. The feed for pigs is prepared beforehand by buying the feed in large amount enough for three months. In one period a breeder can produce eight piggies. After a month, some piggies are sold sequentially, and some are raised for fattening for the next period. Selling piggies and fattening costs in total reach Rp. 4.000.000,- with net income for one period is Rp. 1.500.000,-. This helps Ni Made Wersih meeting her family needs and gives her an enthusiasm in running the business.

Translated from Indonesian by Iman Persada, Kiva volunteer.

Ni Made Wersih Kristiani sudah lama beternak babi. Dengan mengandalkan usaha ini yaitu dengan cara membeli beberapa ekor bibit kemudian dipelihara hanya dua sampai tiga bulan dan dijual kembali bisa mendatangkan pendapatan yang lumayan besar. Dengan bergabungnya menjadi client Dinari kini Ni Made Wersih mulai mencoba membeli satu induk dan rencananya akan dipelihara untuk dapat menghasilkan bibit babi agar tidak membeli bibit di tempat lain. Persediaaan pakan pun sudah dipersiapkan dengan cara membeli dalam jumlah besar untuk keperluan dalam 3 bulan. Dalam satu periode induk babi akan dapat menghasilkan delapan ekor bibit. Setelah bibit dipelihara satu bulan kemudian bibit dijual sebagian secara bertahap dan sebagian akan dipelihara untuk penggemukkan pada tahap berikutnya. Total penjualan bibit dan penggemukkan dapat mencapai Rp. 4.000.000,-dengan keuntungan bersih selama satu periode sebesar Rp.1.500.000,-.Hal ini sangat membantu Ni Made Wersih dalam memenuhi kebutuhan hidup keluarganya dan membuatnya semakin bersemanggat lagi dalam menjalankan usaha ini.

loans.use: To buy pig feed

loans.name: Ni Putu Susilawati

texts.id:
For villagers, farming is one f the most profitable business. Ni Putu Susilawati is a housewife who works hard and diligently to supplement her husband's income to support her family. For a while, Ni Putu Susilawati farms breeding pigs. She owns 2 breeding pigs and 6 piglets. However, lately price of farm feeds are increasing, therefore she could not afford to feed her pigs like before. DINARI foundation is helping her to obtain a loan to help her farm's finances. Besides paying for feeds, she also needs to repair the flooring on her pen. To help pig farmers in the neighborhood, DINARI foundation established a farm feeds depot and veterinary medicines center. DINARI also employs a veterinarian to train Ni Putu Susilawati and other farmers. She hopes that her motivation could be increased once she solved her feed affordability problem.She cleans and takes care of her pigs diligently every day. Every three months, Ni Putu Susilawai can sell her pigles with net profit of around $110. This business helps her supplement her husband's income.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Bagi masyarakat pedesaan beternak adalah suatu kegiatan yang dapat menghasilkan dan menguntungkan. Ni Putu Susilawati adalah salah satu ibu rumah tangga yang senantiasa giat bekerja dan berusaha, untuk memenuhi dan menambah keperluan hidupnya selain dari pendapatan suaminya. Sudah sejak lama Ni Putu Susilawati memelihara induk babi. Total induk 2 ekor dan 6 ekor bibit bibi. Yang menjadi masalah untuk saat ini adalah harga pakan semakin lama semakin mahal , sehingga ketersedian pakan semakin berkurang. Dengan pelayanan Yayasan DINARI yang menjangkau daerahnya, Ni Putu Susilawati mendapat pinjaman dana dan dipakai untuk keperluan usaha ternaknya. Disamping untuk mengatasi masalah pakan ternak dengan cara membeli persediaan pakan juga terpakai untuk memperbaiki lantai kandangnya yang sudah tidak layak lagi. Untuk memenuhi keperluan masyarakat khususnya bagi peternak babi disekitar desanya maka yayasan Dinari membentuk sebuah depo pakan ternak .barang- barang yang dijual yaitu aneka macan pakan ternak dan obat obatnya guna menunjang usaha ternak babinya. Selain itu juga menyediakan dokter hewan untuk membantu dan pembinaan mengenai usaha ternaknya. Dengan ketersediaan pakan yang sudah terpenuhi membuat Ni Putu Susilawati semangat kembali untuk menekuni usaha beternak babinya. Pembersihan, pemeliharaan senantiasa ditekuni setiap harinya. Dalam kurun waktu 3 bulan Ni Putu Susilawati dapat menjual bibit-bibitnya. Dengan keuntungan bersih sebesar Rp.1.000.000,- selalu didapatnya. Usaha inilah yang senantiasa dapat menopang dan menambah pendapatan selain dari usaha dari suaminya.

loans.use: Purchase Feeds

loans.name: Ni Komang

texts.id:
Ni Komang D. has been operating a kiosk since 15 years ago. She sells various daily needs, from staple foods, school supplies and household goods. She needs quite a large fund to operate her kiosk. Since joining DINARI, Ni Komang D. obtained training and possible loan facilities to increase her inventory and offerings. Ni Komang D. opens her kiosk at 6 am and closes at 9pm each day. Besides operating her kiosk, Ni Komang D. goes to the market to buy goods to be resold every three days. Sometimes she gets her goods from roaming salespeople. Currently Ni Komang D. lives with her husband and 2 children who is already in the workforce and enrolled in high school. Her kiosk sales is about $11 to $22 per day with $3.30 to $5.50 profit per day. With this earnings, Ni Komang D. supports her husband, Made Anggrawiana and her two children.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Ni Komang D. menekuni usaha warung sejak 15 tahun yang lalu. Barang yang dijual bermacam-macam mulai dari bahan makanan pokok , keperluan alat- alat sekolah dan alat- alat keperluan rumah tangga. Modal yang yang diperlukan memang tidak sedikit untuk melengkapi keperluan usaha warungnya. Semenjak bergabung dengan DINARI , Ni Komang D. mendapat pembinaan dan mendapat kepercayaan sehingga memperoleh pinjaman dana, sehingga dapat melengkapi keperluan usaha warungnya yang beberapa lalu belum terpenuhi. Ni Komang D. membuka warungnya pada pukul 06.00 wita dan ditutup pukul 21.00 wita. Selain menunggui warung, Ni Komang D. juga dapat mengerjakan pekerjaan dirumahnya sebab warung terletak didepan rumahnya.Untuk melengkapi warungnya Ni Komang D. setiap tiga hari sekali berbelanja di dipasar, selain itu juga ada beberapa barang yang selalu diantar oleh sales keliling. Saat ini komang Dami tinggal bersama suami dan kedua orang anaknya yang sudah bekerja dan sekolah pada tingkat atas. Total pendapatan yang diperoleh dalam sehari mencapi Rp.100.000,- sampai dengan Rp.200.000,- dengan keuntungan bersih yang diperolehRp.30.000,-sampai Rp.50.000,- dengan keuntungan inilah Ni Komang D. mencukupi keperluan sehari-harinya bersama dengan suaminya, Made Anggrawiana dan kedua anaknya.

loans.use: Purchase additional Inventory

loans.name: Ni Ketut

texts.id:
While Ni Ketut R. is no longer young, she is still diligent in pursuing her business to trade red sugar. She obtains her merchandise by going around the neighborhood helped by her husband, I Made Ronten. This business was used to support her family. She found DINARI through her local women's organization. She sought to get a loan from DINARI to trade coconut sugar. She gets 5 cents per 1 kg coconut. She can sell about 60kg daily, so she nets $3 daily profit. Demand for red sugar increases around Hindu festivals, so she earns more during those days. She has been involved in coconut sugar trading business for the past 20 years. She hopes the loan would help her expand her business.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Ni Ketut R. di usia yang sudah tidak muda lagi masih tetap giat menekuni usahanya berjual beli gula kelapa. Barang dagangannya diperoleh dengan mencari secara keliling pada pelanggannya dan dibantu oleh suaminya, I Made Ronten . Usaha inilah yang dapat dilakukan untuk menopang keperluan dalam keluarganya. Melalui Tempek ( kumpulan ibu – ibu dalam satu wilayah ) yang ada desanya, Ni Ketut R. mengenal DINARI dan diberi kepercayaan dan mendapat dana pinjaman. Dana tersebut dipakai untuk menambah modal usahanya dalam berjual beli gula kelapa. Keuntungan yang didapat dalam setiap 1 kilogram gula kelapa hanya Rp. 500,- . Dalam sehari Ni Ketut R. dapat memperoleh dagangan paling sedikit sebanyak 60 kg. Jadi keuntungan bersih yang didapat dapat sehari mencapai Rp.30.000,- Permintaan gula merah meningkat apabila sudah mendekati hari raya-hari raya umat Hindhu, sehingga keuntungan lebih meningkat lagi. Usaha gula kelapa ini sudah ditekuni selalu 20 tahun yang lalu. Dengan harapan kedepannya usaha akan semakin meningkat sehingga taraf kehidupan ekonominya akan lebih meningkat lagi.

loans.use: Purchase Red Sugar to be sold

loans.name: Ni Made

texts.id:
Ni Made M. is a highly motivated housewife. Due to her diligence in praying everyday, she realized that there is an opportunity to start worship supplies business. She sells things like saucer, basket, broom, flower, coconut leaves, etc. She obtains the ingredient from her neighbors' backyards. After collecting raw materials, she sells her products in the market. Some buyers come directly to her home. To increase volume and purchase more ingredients, Ni Made M. needs more capital. Through her local women's organization, No Made M. obtained additional capital and training from DINARI which helped her tremendously. From this business, Ni Made M. may obtain up to $2.20 - $3.30 profit which may supplement her husband's income, I Putu Denen, who works as a farmer.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Ni Made M. adalah seorang ibu rumah tangga yang tidak pantang menyerah dan tekun dalam mencari peluang usaha. Karena setiap hari melakukan sembahyang dan memerlukan prasarana yang digunakan, maka secara kecil - kecilan Ni Made M. menyediakan bahan untuk prasarana sembahyang. Barang yang dijual seperti aneka canang sari, keranjang, semat, sapu lidi, janur dan lain-lain. Bahan baku didapat dengan cara membeli dikebun - kebun tetangga. Setelah barang dagangan terkumpul biasanya Nii Made M. menjualnya di pasar dan ada beberapa pembeli yang datang langsung kerumahnya.Untuk meningkatkan usahanya dan untuk membeli bahan baku lebih banyak lagi, Ni Made M. memerlukan tambahan modal. Melalui organisasi ibu – ibu didesanya Ni Made M. memperoleh tambahan dana dan pembinaan - pembinaan dari Yayasan DINARI yang tentunya sangat bermanfaat dalam melangsungkan perjalanan usahanya. Dengan usaha inilah Ni Made M. dapat memperoleh keuntungan bersih sekitar Rp. 20.000,- s/d Rp. 30.000,-. Dari keuntungan ini dapat menambah membantu penghasilan suaminya, I Putu Denen, yang seorang petani dan dapat untuk memenuhi

loans.use: Purchase raw materials

loans.name: Ni Nyoman

texts.id:
Ni Nyoman W. lives with her husband, Nyoman Tunas. To fulfill the family's daily need, Nyoman Tunas works as a contract labor with uncertain income. To supplement her family's income, Ni Nyoman W. sells traditional Balinese snack. She learned to make the snacks from her parents. She buys ingredients from the local market. To support the business, Ni Nyoman W. wants to obtain loan from DINARI Foundation. Besides funding assistance, Nyoman W. also obtained training. She earns $3.30 daily which is sufficient to fulfill her family's daily needs with her husband.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Ni Nyoman W. sekarang hanya tinggal dengan suaminya yaitu Nyoman Tunas.Untuk memenuhi keperluan keluarganya Nyoman Tunas bekerja sebagai buruh yang pendapatannya tidak tetap. Untuk menambah pendapatan dalam keluarga Ni Nyoman W. tidak tinggal diam dan hanya mengandalkan suaminya. Dengan segala keterbatasanya yang dapat dilakukan hanyalah membuat kue tradisioanal Bali. Pengalaman ini diadapat karena sudah terbiasa membuat sendiri bersama orang tuanya sejak dulu. Bahan baku didapat dari pasar. Dalam menunjang usahanya Ni Nyoman W. mendapat pinjaman dari Yayasan DINARI. Selain pinjaman dana, juga memperoleh pembinaan-pembinaan untuk memajukan usahanya. Keuntungan bersih yang didapat dari usahanya mencapai Rp. 30.000,- dalam sehari. Ini semua cukup untuk memenuhi keperluan sehari - hari bersama dengan suaminya.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients, e.g. flour, sugar

loans.name: Joaquim Ernesto

texts.pt:
Joaquim Ernesto M. is 36 years old; he lives in a social marriage and is the father of 3 sons. He lives in the neighborhood of Hulene, outside of the city of Maputo. Besides being a teacher at the local public school, he is also a tailor and runs his business out of his house. He joined the program in April of 2007 and because he joined so recently it is too soon to tell the progression of his business. He will borrow 10,000MT to invest in the bulk purchase of fabrics, threads, needles and other supplies needed to grow his business.

Translated by Camila, Kiva volunteer

Joaquim Ernesto M. tem 36 anos de idade, vive maritalmente e é pai de 3 filhos.Vive no bairro Hulene, arredores da cidade de Maputo.É alfaiate e tem o seu negócio na sua residência, para além de ser professor numa escola comunitária situada no seu bairro. Entrou para o programa em Abril de 2007, sendo ainda prematuro avaliar a sua evolução. Vai tomar 10.000MT para investir na compra em quantidade de tecidos, linhas, agulhas e outros materiais e utensílios necessários ao seu negócio.

loans.use:
Purchase of fabrics, threads, needles, etc.

Compra de tecidos,linhas, agulhas, etc

loans.name: Musawa Women's Group

texts.en:
Harriet Hamubiru is the 38-year-old chairperson of the Musaua Women’s Group in Katwe. She is married with 4 children. For the past nine years, she has operated a health store which sells vitamins and health care items. Group Loan Disbursement meetings are always interesting. One has to have patience. We arrived in Katwe, a slum area on the outskirts of Kampala around 3:00PM. Most disbursements occur in the afternoon because the chairperson and treasury have to go to the bank, collect the money, and return to their village. Sometimes even lines at banks can be a couple of hours. Once they have returned to the village, someone is sent out to tell all the members that it is time to meet.

We arrived at the meeting place, a simple concrete home in Katwe. Most homes are adobe. Removing our shoes, we entered through the draped doorway. We took our seat on a comfortable but worn sofa and waited. Over the next two hours, people arrived and took a place on the floor. We waited for all to arrive. As people came through the draped doorway into the darkened room, they would greet us with “You are most welcome” and then take their place in the room. By the time all had arrived, there were 28 persons in a 12ft. by 12ft. room lit only by the light of the doorway. There is a peaceful calm in groups. Ugandans rarely raise their voices. In groups they are soft-spoken to the point of whispers, even when addressing the entire group.

Harriet’s portion of the group loan is $300US. With her loan, she plans on buying more health care items for her store. She dreams of one day being able to buy a plot of land and build some houses that she can rent.

loans.use: Harriet plans to use her loan to purchase more health care items for her drug store.

loans.name: Angélica Adriano

texts.pt:
Angélica Adiano C. is a 45-year-old married mother of 5. She lives in the Magoanine neighborhood and runs her business at the local market. She entered the program in May of 2007 with a loan amount of 5,000 MT. She sells vegetables and some essential retail products such as rice, sugar, seasonings, etc. She is seeking a loan of 5,000 MT to increase her stock.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Angélica Adiano C. tem 45 anos de idade, vive maritalmente e é mãe de 5 filhos. Vive no bairro Magoanine e tem o seu negócio no mercado do mesmo bairro. Entrou para o programa em maio de 2007 com um empréstimo de 5.000MT. Vende Legumes e alguns produtos de primeira necessidade a retalho como arroz, açúcar, tempereos, etc. Vai tomar um empréstimo de 5.000Mt para aumentar o stock do negócio.

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent owns a wholesale beverage depot in the village of Nansana. He is a distributor of sodas and beer which he sells in cases to retailers. Most villages have one distributor. He will purchase quantities of 200 cases at a time with 24 bottles to a case. A case of soda will cost him 9700 shillings, or about 400 shillings per bottle. He will then sell it to the retailer who will sell it to the customer for 500 shillings. So, the gross profit earned between both the wholesaler and the retailer is about 100 shillings per bottle. 100 shillings is about five cents.

Vincent has been a distributor since 1993. This is an excellent business, because you have a contract with the bottler and you have little competition. Sodas and beer are relatively inexpensive, and they offer a simple luxury that even the people of the villages can occasionally afford, although often alcohol is homemade. Vincent has been in operation since 1993 and with his lending group for the past nine years. With his loan, he plans on stocking more beverages. Eventually he would like to be able to afford a vehicle, buy some land, and build a house.

loans.use: Vincent plans to use his loan to buy more beverages for his wholesale business.

loans.name: Estrela Drive-In Group

texts.pt:
The group entered the program in 2005 with an initial loan of 1800 MT. They are now in their 8th cycle. They have been performing quite well and running their businesses successfully. The group leader is Amelia Alberto T.. Amelia is 36 years of age and unmarried but lives with a partner and her 3 children in the Zimpeto neighborhood. She sells construction materials, furnaces, etc. The group is now taking a loan of 5,600 MT to invest in the business, to be repaid in 4 months.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

O grupo entrou no programa em 2005 começou a tomar o valor de 1800 e agroa encontra se no 8º ciclo tem se comportado muito bem esta desenvolver bem os seus negócios, a lider do grupo é Amelia Alberto T. Tem 36 anos de idade não é casada mais vive maritalmente tem 3 filhos vive no bairro do Zimpeto, vende Material de contrução , fugões etc, o grupo vai tomar o valor de 5.600,00mt para pagar em 4 meses para investir no negócio .

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en:
Sarah is the chairperson of the Byona Biyinzika Lending Group in the village of Nansana. She is married, 56 years old, and has 10 children and 6 dependents. She has two businesses: a poultry business and a health drug business. The health drug business consists of vitamins, nutritional supplements and products for HIV/AIDS prevention and care. She distributes the items throughout different markets. She is hoping to one day open a central depot for dispensing. She has been operating the business for four years and has been a member of her lending group for the past 9 years.

Sarah also has just begun a poultry business. She currently has 25 broilers which she raises from week-old chicks. Within approximately 2 months, they will be ready for market. Sarah’s portion of the group loan is approximately $400US. With her loan, she plans to buy more health products to distribute in the markets.

loans.use: Sarah plans to use her loan to buy more health care products for her business.

loans.name: Sabrohon

texts.ru:
Sabrohon, 57, is married and has 5 children. In spite of her age, Sabrohon actively engaged in business to help provide for her family. At present, Sabrohon, with the help of her daughter and granddaughter, raises cattle. Sabrohon has been a MicroInvest client for 1.5 years. She asks for this loan to finance a purchase of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Sabrohon 57 лет. Она замужем и у нее 5 детей. Она старается, несмотря на возраст заняться предпринимательской деятельностью, чтобы получить доход для своей семьи. На данный момент она занимается животноводством – откормом скота. В этом ей помогают ее дочь и внуки. С Микроинвест она сотрудничает уже 1,5 года. новый займ она просит для закупки корма для скота.

loans.use: To purchase food for cattle

loans.name: Wasafiri Group

texts.en:
Anne A. O. has a tailoring business with two sewing machines. The business is located in a low income estate on the outskirts of Kisumu town called “Nyalenda”. Anne, 38 years old, has operated this business for the last 5 years. She buys clothing materials and makes clothes for both genders out of these materials. She intends to buy more clothing materials with the money from this loan so that she can increase her variety and volume.

Anne is married with 8 children and cares for two orphans. Her husband is engaged in the informal sector as a local mechanic. Her husband is not able to support the family with his income alone and Anne has been supplementing the family income with her business. Her children, together with the two orphans, are going to school and this places an extra burden on Anne to help pay for school fees for all of the children. Anne hopes to lighten this burden through increased profits that she hopes to get from her business by buying more clothing materials with the loan.

This is the first loan that Anne is taking together with the whole group. The group is cohesive and the leaders have displayed a high sense of responsibility during training period. Anne has done her duties with a high degree of diligence particularly in ensuring that the group documents are well kept and all the members attend the group meetings. Anne hopes to use this group platform to acquire more loans in future and she hopes to continue investing much of her time in her group secretarial duties to have the group maintain the current cohesion they have so far displayed.

Note: Abednego Ouma is also pictured in the group photo and is a member of the group but is not taking a loan in this cycle.

loans.use: To increase stock for her tailoring business

loans.name: Adozinda Luis

texts.pt:
Adozinda Luis X., 35 years of age, holder of ID Card No. 110032261P, a native and resident of Maputo in the Magoanine neighborhood, 9th Quarter, House no. 45, unmarried but living with a partner, has 3 children and lives in her own home. She entered the program on March 29, 2006, and is in her 3rd cycle. She started as part of a group, taking an initial loan of 1,800 MT. She left the group and is now seeking an individual loan of 6,000 MT to be repaid in 5 months. She sells wrap skirts and blouses. She plans to use the loan to expand the business by purchasing more products, clothing, purses, etc. She is a traveling saleswoman.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Adozinda Luis X. , de 35 anos de Idade, Portadora do BI nº110032261P, natural de Maputo Residente na Cidade de Maputo no Bairro Magoanine Quarteirão 9 casa nº 45 ,não casada mais vive maritalmente, tem 3 filhos, entrou no projecto a 29/03/06 vive em casa propria esta no 3º ciclo e entrou primeiro como elemento de um grupo tamando no principio 1800 e sai do grupo agora toma individualmente vai tomar 6000 para pagar em 5 meses ela Vende capulanas , Blusas , Com o valor ela pretende Ampliar o negocio comprando mais produtos roupas , carteiras etc.o seu tipo de Negocio e Vendedora Ambulante.

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Izafat

texts.en: Izafat has been in this business for 3 years. He is 42 years old, married, and has 2 children. He and his family live in the Salyan region in the village of Yenikand. He would like to improve the conditions of his cafe to attract more clients; therefore he is applying for a loan of $725 to buy glasses, teapots, kettles and sugar bowls.

loans.use: to buy glasses, teapots, kettles and sugar bowls

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Adérito Ananias

texts.pt:
Adérito Ananias Z., holder of ID Card No. 110884006V, a native and resident of the Mavalane neighborhood of Maputo, 5th Quarter, House No. 128, is married and has one child. He entered the program on June 26, 2007, with a loan amount of 3,000 MT. He is now in his 2nd cycle. He will take another loan of 3,000 MT to be repaid in 4 months. He operates his business in the province of Gaza, in the districts of Chokwe and Manjacaze. He continually travels to conduct business due his distance from Maputo.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Adérito Ananias Z., Portador do BI nº 110884006V, Natural de Maputo Residente em Maputo no bairro ,de Mavalane, Quarteirão nº 5 casa nº128 , tem 1 filho vive maritalmente, entrou no programa a 26/06/07 a tomar o valor de 3000 mt esta no 2º ciclo, vai tomar novamente o valor de 3000 mt para pagar em 4 meses ele pratica o seu negocio na provincia de Gaza Nos Distritos de Chokwe, Manjacaze e faz sempre viajens para fazer o seu negocio por é distante de Maputo.

loans.use: Increase business

loans.name: Zinyat

texts.en: Zinyat G. is a mother of 2 children. This 45-year-old woman lives with her family in the Khaladj village in the Salyan region. She has run her own farm for the past 8 years. Zinyat has requested a loan of $1200 to buy fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Xayyam

texts.en:
H. Xayyam is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Azerbaijan- Armenian conflict territory in the Jebrayil region, situated in the western part of Azerbaijan. He settled with his family in Sumgayit city. He is 40 years old. He is married and has 2 children. Xayyam is the only breadwinner in his family.

After borrowing $500 in 2004 from Normicro, he rented a shop. He borrowed a second loan of $800 and built the grocery store. The loans were paid back on time. With his third loan of $900, he expanded the area of the shop and increased the food assortments.

Now, he needs $1,400 to expand his business, open a vegetable section, and buy digital scales. He will borrow $200 of this loan from Normicro and the other $1,200 from KIVA. He hopes eventually to expand his business. He will repay his loan on a monthly basis.

loans.use: To expand his business, open a vegetable section, and buy digital scales.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Carlota Samuel

texts.pt:
Carlota Samuel M., holder of ID Card No. 110509343R, single, 32 years of age, living with her spouse and 2 children, is a native of Maputo and resident of the George Dimitrov neighborhood, house number 38, in Maputo. This is her first time in the program. She will start off with a loan of 6,000 MT to be repaid in 4 months. This is her first cycle. She sells essential products in Bobol, a district of Maputo that is about 50 km outside the city. She plans to use the loan to invest in the growth of the business.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Carlota Samuel M., portadora do BI nº110509343R, Solteira, de 32 anos de Idade vive martalmente e tem 2 filhos natural de Maputo, Residente No Bairro George Dimitrov Casa nº38 em Maputo, primeira vez no progama vai iniciar tomando o valor de 6000 para pagar em 4 meses é o primeiro ciclo ela vende produtos de 1º necessidade e bobol um Distrito de Maputo Fica quaze 50 km da Cidade de Maputo pretende com esse valor aumentar o negocio.

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.pt:
Beatriz B., holder of Passport No. AB 226509, 38 years of age and a resident of the Laulane / 3 de fevereiro neighborhood, is married with 1 child and lives in her own home. She will begin the program by borrowing 6,000 MT to be repaid in 6 months. She sells clothing and is a traveling saleswoman. She plans to use the loan to invest in the business.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Beatriz B., portadora do passapot nº AB 226509, de 38 anos de idade residente no bairro Laulane / 3 de fevereiro, casada e tem 1 filho casa propria esta a iniciar no programa, vai tomar 6000 para pagar em 6 meses ,vende Roupas é vendedora ambulante e com o valor que vai tomar pretende Investir no negocio

loans.use: Increase stock

loans.name: Shakhriyar

texts.en: Shakhriyar A. is a 22-year-old single man who lives in Khaladj village in the Salyan region. He has 5 years of experience in this business. This man needs a loan of $1,200 to buy balling presses to improve his cattle business.

loans.use: to buy balling presses for his cattle business

loans.name: Djeyhun

texts.en: Djeyhun (his sister is pictured) has his own business. He was born in 1984 and lives in the Salyan region in the village of Yenikand. This man is single. He has been in this business for 8 years. Now he needs a loan of $1,200 to buy foodstuffs for improving his business.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Murad

texts.en:
G. Murad is 35 years old, married, and the father of one child. He is from the Azerbaijan- Armenian conflict territory in the Zengilan region, situated in the western part of the Azerbaijan Republic in the Caucasus. Right now he lives with his family in Sumqayit city. He is a low-income person who is very vulnerable to shifts in the local economy.

Murad has a small flock of sheep. He buys lambs and raises them in 6 months. He sells the sheep in the local market, buys other lambs, and spends the rest of his profit to provide all the necessities of life for his family. His wife helps him with his work. In 2005, Murad borrowed $300 from Normicro and expanded his business. For his second loan, he borrowed $500 and bought seven other sheep.

Now he would like to receive a $900 loan in order to acquire 10 sheep, improve the pen, and buy feed for them. He will repay the loan within 12 months. He hopes eventually to expand his business, and this will further improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: To acquire 10 sheep, improve the pen, and buy feed for them

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Norwegian Microcredit LLC (Normicro) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Dora

texts.en: Mrs. Dora A. is 48 years old, a widow with five children, and she lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells jewelry and accessories in an open market. This is a business she learned for 6 months before she opened hers. She is soliciting a loan of $275 to enable her to buy more jewelry to sell.

loans.use: Dora would like to buy more jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Mrs. Helen I. is 45 years old, is married with five children, and she lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells cooked food, water and drinks to people living in her community. She learned her business from her mother as a child. According to her, with $450 she will be able to buy more water and drink to sell.

loans.use: Helen woud like to buy more foodstuffs & drinks to sell.

loans.name: Itohan

texts.en: Mrs. Itohan A. is 45 years old and married with eight children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has a shop where she sells provisions and drinks. She has been in this business for the past 8 years. She is an LAPO member and she is requesting a loan of $350 to buy more stock.

loans.use: Itohan would like to buy more provisions and drinks

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mrs. Mercy I. is 40 years old and is married with five children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She goes to the village market and buys melon, ogbolor and peppers and sells them to people in her community. She learned this business for 6 months from a friend and opened hers in 2002. She is in need of a loan of $275 to buy more supplies to sell.

loans.use: Mercy would like to buy more pepper, melon and ogbolor to sell.

loans.name: Asiyat

texts.en: Asiyat was born in 1958 and lives in Khachmaz town. She is single. This woman has been in this business for 4 years. She has sold cloth. Now she needs a loan of $850 to buy cloth and clothes.

loans.use: to buy cloth and clothes

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Mrs. Grace O. sells clothes in an open market. She is 39 years old, is married with five children and lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She learned this business for 2 years and has 3 years experience in the business. She is an LAPO member and needs a loan of $600 to buy more clothes to sell. She wishes to pay back the loan in 8 months.

loans.use: Grace would like to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Oghogho

texts.en: Mrs. Oghogho Uyi is 37 years old, is married with six children, and she lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells wood (planks) to people. She has been in this business since 1998 and she is requesting a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more wood to sell.

loans.use: Oghogho would like to buy more wood to sell.

loans.name: Morn

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Morngot married in 1970 and has nine children: six sons and three daughters. Since 1999, she has run a business buying and reselling small trees in her village. Five of her children are married and live in different houses with their families. Her four other children live with her. Two of them help her in her tree sales business and the other two work in a garment factory in the Ta Khmao district. Her husband works two jobs as a gardener and construction worker.

Mrs M. has borrowed money from MAXIMA four times to date. She is now requesting a $300 loan with which to build a restroom and make repairs to her house.

loans.use: To build a restroom and repair her house.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Sovannary

texts.en:
Miss. T. Sovannary is single (aged 21) and lives with her parents, two brothers and a sister. She began her silk production business at home in 2002 after learning to weave silk from her elder sister. Today, besides engaging in farming activities, her mum and dad also weave silk at home.

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA, her first, for $400. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the existing loom and also to create another loom.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, fees for selecting and preparing silk on the existing loom and to create a new loom.

loans.name: Sopha

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Sopha got married in 2006 and has one son. She runs a business weaving silk at home. She began her silk production in 2003 after she learned to weave silk from her mother. Even though she is married, she lives with her parents in Koh Dach village.

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA, her first, for $500. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom and some will be used to repair her family's house.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom and to repair her house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en: Mrs. Racheal I. is 32 years old and married with three children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells clothes including babywear. She has been in this business for a long time. She is in need of a loan of $450 to enable her to buy more clothing and babywear to sell. She promises to repay the loan.

loans.use: Racheal would like to buy more babywear and clothing to sell.

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Ny (aged 52) got married in 1980 and has five children: three sons and two daughters. She runs a business weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her mother in 1966 and began her silk production in that year. However, during the years of rule by the Khmer Rouge regime, her family fled to live in other provinces and she stopped her weaving work. She restarted silk production in 1979.

Mrs K. also buys and resells silk products which she buys from villagers in the community. Her two youngest children weave silk at home with her. The other three work in different businesses. Her husband is a farmer, growing papaya, gourd and eggplant in the village.

Mrs K. has borrowed money from MAXIMA thrice. She is now requesting a $100 loan to purchase silk materials and sewing thread.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials and sewing thread

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Nan

texts.en:
Mrs. POV Nan (aged 52) got married in 1979 and has six children: three sons and three daughters. She runs a business weaving silk at home. In fact, she learned to weave silk from her mother in 1968 and began her silk production in that year. However, during the years of rule by the Khmer Rouge regime, she did not weave. She restarted her silk production in 1979, the year she got married. Her husband is a mechanic who repairs machines.

Mrs Pov is requesting a MAXIMA loan, her first, for $300 She will use this money to expand her silk production by purchasing silk materials, sewing thread and covering fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread and  pay for fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Mrs. Faith I. is 36 years old and married with four children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells building materials and provisions. She learned this business for 3 months and opened hers in 1999. She is in need of a loan of $450 to buy more provisions and building materials such as wash basins, pipes, etc. to sell.

loans.use: Faith would like to buy more toilet seats, hand wash basins and pipes etc.

loans.name: Sopheab

texts.en:
Mrs. P. Sopheab (aged 29) got married in 2002 and has one daughter. She runs a business weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 1990 and began her silk production in the same year. She has trained her husband to weave as well. Her husband, Mr. Chun Chin, also fishes for a living. As they both did not complete primary school, they are committed to seeing that their daughter completes her higher education. She currently attends the kindergarten school in their village.

Mrs P. has borrowed money from MAXIMA thrice. She is now requesting a $200 loan to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use:
To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, pay fees for 
selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Mrs. Blessing O. is 39 years old, she is a widow with six children, and she lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells foodstuffs and provisions. This is a business she learned from her sister and she is in need of $525 to enable her to buy more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: Blessing would like to buy more foodstuffs, drinks & provisions to sell.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Mrs. Joy I. is 45 years old, is married with four children, and she lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells fairly used clothes. She is requesting a loan of $450 to buy more fairly used clothes to sell and promises to repay it within 8 months. She has 8 years experience in business.

loans.use: Joy would like to buy more fairly used clothes to sell in her shop.

loans.name: Sambo

texts.en:
Mr. S. Sambo has been married since 1985 and has four childre:three sons and one daughter. He fishes his small and old boat along the river within the district. He plans to expand his fishing business by purchasing a new boat and equiping it with a motor. His wife, Mrs. Ry Srey, is currently in the business of weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 1980 and began her own silk production in the same year. She also farms in the village.

Mr S. has borrowed money from MAXIMA thrice already. Now he is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a boat, machine and fishing net and to expand his wife's silk production.

loans.use:
To purchase a boat, machine and fishing net and to expand 
silk production

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mrs. Mercy O. is 40 years old and married with five children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells cooked food, drinks and provisions in her shop. She has learned this business from her mother since childhood and she has 10 years of experience in this business. She is seeking a loan of $525 to enable her to buy more foodstuffs, drinks and provisions to sell.

loans.use: Mercy would like to buy more rice, beans and provisions to sell.

loans.name: Heat

texts.en:
Mr. T. Heat (aged 41) and his family live in a small village near the Mekong River about twenty kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Heat and his wife (aged 42), have been married since 1986 and have five children, four of whom study in school. One boy does not attend school due to a hearing problem so he takes care of the family’s cows along with other household work. His wife sells fish in the market in their village. Heat himself attended school through grade seven and his wife attended through grade four.

Like many men in this area, Heat has been fishing since he was a boy. He is requesting this, his second loan from Maxima, to buy a second-hand fishing boat and a new motor for the boat. He said that a boat should cost around (US) $600 and the motor will cost $400. In addition to supporting his family, during the fishing season he employs as many as ten men paying each between $2.50 and $3.75 per day. Heat expressed concern that the future of fishing in this area does not look so positive. Catches are a third of what they were five years ago but he wants to continue fishing because that’s what his father and grandfather did. He also gets income from raising cows, farming and (interestingly) fortune telling.

loans.use: To purchase a second-hand fishing boat and a boat motor.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en: Mrs. Beauty I. is 43 years old and married with seven children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She learned this business for 3 years and started hers in 1999. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy more drinks & yams to sell.

loans.use: Beauty would like to buy more yams and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en: Mrs. Blessing U. is 26 years old and married with a child. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is a hairdresser by profession; she fixes hair, braids hair, sells weavon, hair cream, etc. to people living in her community. She learned this business in a year and opened hers in 2005. She is requesting a loan of $875 to enable her to buy weavon, relaxer and hair cream to sell.

loans.use: Blessing would like to buy more weavon, hair cream and a refrigerator for her beauty salon.

loans.name: Sles Tol's Group

texts.en:
These three families live in a small village near the Mekong River about twenty kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Like many men in this area, the husbands have all been fishing since they were boys. Two of them, Mr. S. Math and Mr. S. Ousman, were fishing at the time of the loan interview. They do not appear in this photograph. They are requesting this, their first group loan from Maxima, to buy fishing nets, a second-hand motor for one boat and for general boat repair costs.

1- Mr. S. Tol (aged 45) and his wife (center couple in image) married in 1989. They have six children, three of whom study in the village school. One son fishes with his father. His wife takes care of the children and household as well as sells the fish her husband catches. They are saving to buy a car that they will then use as a taxi. They are requesting a loan from MAXIMA for US$300 and will use this money to buy fishing nets and a second-hand motor for his fishing boat.

2- Mr. S. Math (aged 39) and his wife (far right of image) married in 1990. They have four children, two of whom study in the village school. His wife sells green papaya salad at the afternoon market along the lane that runs through their village. They are requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time for $US100 and will use this money to buy fishing nets.

3- Mr. S. Ousman (aged 44) and his wife (far left of image) married in 1986. They have six children, two of whom study in school, two of whom have stopped studying and two of whom are physically disabled. His wife describes the disability as “their arms and legs don’t work”. She said that the children must be fed, clothed, bathed and be given assistance with any other activity requiring mobility. S. and his wife also farm - both to provide food for the house and to supplement their income. They are requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time of $US200 and will use this money to buy fishing nets and to cover general boat repair costs.

loans.use: Group loan to purchase fishing nets, a boat motor and to repair fishing boats.

loans.name: Tun

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Tun is a widow with three children: two sons and a daughter. She began running a business weaving silk in 1982, having learnt how to weave silk from her mother. After working for a year, her skills were good enough to start weaving independently. Her daughter works in a restaurant. Of her two sons, one is carpenter and the other attends the primary school in the village.

Tun is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $200. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and pay for the preparation of her loom.

loans.use: Buy silk materials and prepare loom

loans.name: Sam Ath

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoeung Sam Ath was married in 1989 and has three children, two sons and one daughter. She is currently in the business of weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her mother in 1984 and began her silk production in the same year. Her husband, Mr. Prak Bunthorn is a carpenter. He learned this skill from his father in 1992. Sam Ath’s daughter is a cleaner in a club in Phnom Penh. Her other two sons are studying in a local school. So, Sam Ath and her husband are committed to their sons achieving a higher education.

Sam Ath has borrowed money from MAXIMA for the first time. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $500. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use:
To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for 
selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Vorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Y. Vorn (age 57) was married in 1967 and has five children, four sons and one daughter. She is currently in the business of weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 1985 and began her silk production in the same year. Her daughter is also weaving silk with her at home. Vorn has not finished primary school. Her husband, Mr. Ou Kot is a farmer. He grows rice, plants vegetables, and raises cows. He never attends school.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA four times already. Now she is requesting a loan in the amount of $200. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use:
To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for 
selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Dorn

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Dorn (age 38) was married in 1990 and has one daughter. She is currently in the business of weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 1987 and began her silk production in the same year. She has not finished primary school. Her husband, Mr. Vat Sam Ath is a carpenter. He learnt this skill in 2000. He has finished secondary school. They both are committed to their daughter's higher education. Now their daughter is being sent to the kindergarten school in their village.

Dorn has borrowed money from MAXIMA for the third time. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $500. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use:
To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for 
selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Tong

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Tong (age 59) was married in 1960 and has six children, three sons and three daughters. She is currently in the business of weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her mother in law in 1979 and began her silk production in the same year. One of her daughters is also weaving silk. Her husband, Mr. Chay Phat (age 59) is a farmer. He learnt this skill from his parents in 1979. He fishes, plants corn, and raises cows. One of his sons is also assisting him in raising cows.

Tong has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times before. Now she is requesting a loan to continue her weaving business in the amount of $400. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use:
To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for 
selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Ros (age 59) was married in 1965 and has seven children, six sons and one daughter. She is currently in the business of weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 1960 and began her silk production in the same year. Her husband, Mr. Ry Sok (age 62) is a farmer. Five of her children are married and live in separate houses from her.

Ros has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times before. Now she is requesting a loan to continue her weaving business in the amount of $100. She will use this money to purchase silk materials for preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use:
To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for 
selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Yoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Y. Yoeun (age 49) was married in 1978 and has eight children, six sons and two daughters. He is currently in the business of farming. He learned this skill from his parents in 1979. His wife, Mrs. Sam Samon (age 47) weaves silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her parents in 1980 and began her silk production in the same year. Six of Yoeun’s children are studying in the local school, two of whom are studying at the University of Phnom Penh, and another daughter is sewing clothes at home.

He has borrowed money from MAXIMA six times already. Now he is requesting a loan in the amount of $200. He will use this money to purchase a sewing machine for his daughter.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine for his daughter

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mr. S. San (age 37) was married in 1987 and has four children, two sons and two daughters. He is currently in the business of farming and selling cows. He learned his skill from his friend in 1998. His wife, Mrs.That Oun (age 38) weaves silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her relative in 2006 and began her silk production in the same year. They both are committed to their children gaining higher education.

He has borrowed money from MAXIMA for first time in the amount of $500. He will use this money to purchase cows to resell.

loans.use: To purchase cows for reselling

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Tem

texts.en:
Mrs. T. Tem (age 50) was married in 1979 and has six children, three sons and three daughters. She has been in the business of selling cupcakes since 1985. She makes cupcakes by herself at home to sell in the village everyday. Her husband, Mr. Korn Som (age 55) is currently in the business of growing rice. He started his rice farm in 1979. All of Tem’s daughters are working in a garment factory in Pon-nhealeu district. One of her sons is a construction worker and the other two are studying in the local school.

She is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of $500. She will use this money to purchase a water pumping machine for the farming business.

loans.use: Purchasing water pumping machine

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah A. is happily married with five children. She is 38 years old and comes from Ajamgbandin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She grinds pepper, tomatoes and beans for people living in her community. She has been in this business since 1997 and she is in need of a loan of $450 to buy bathing slippers to add to her shop to sell. She said it will enable her to add an additional source of income.

loans.use: Hannah would like to buy bathroom slippers to sell.

loans.name: Chanthou

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Chanthou (age 32) was married in 1996 and has three children, two sons and one daughter. She is currently in the business of weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her mother in 1988 and began her silk production in the same year. She lives with her mother who is currently weaving silk too. She did not even finish primary school. Her husband has been working in a brick kiln since 1988. He has not finished primary school either. Two of Chanthou’s children are studying at primary school in the village and the youngest one is at home.

Chanthou has borrowed money from MAXIMA six times already. Now she is requesting a loan in the amount of $550. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use:
To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay fees for 
selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en:
Mrs. H. Pich (age 32) and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Pich and her husband, married since 1993, have six children, three of whom attend school in their village and her eldest daughter assists her in selling vegetables.

She is requesting this, her second loan with Maxima in the amount of US$1000, to buy a vegetable farm. Pich has been selling vegetables for four years. Her husband is a farmer. He has been farming and raising animals for many years. Pich and her husband hope to continue to grow their business so they can support their children’s studies to the highest possible level.

loans.use: To purchase vegetable farm.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Sokun

texts.en: Mrs. S. Sokun (age 30) and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River about eighteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh.  Sokun and her husband, married since 1997, have two children, one son and one daughter. Her son attends school in the village and her daughter is still young and stays at home. Currently, Sokun is in the business of selling fish in the village. She has been selling fish since 2000 and her husband produces rice wine and raises pigs.  He started his work in 2005. She is requesting this, her first loan with Maxima in the amount of US$500, to buy equipment for producing rice wine. Sokun and her husband hope to continue to grow their business so they can support her children’s studies to the highest possible level.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for producing rice wine

loans.name: Yeng

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Yeng (age 40) and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River about eighteen kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Yeng and her husband, married since 1989, have four children, three sons and one daughter. Two of her children attend school in the village.

Currently, Yeng is in the business of raising pigs. Her husband, Mr. Kean Han (age 39) is selling blankets and pillows on his old motorbike going from one village to another. Two of Yeng’s sons are buying and reselling recyclable materials. She is requesting this, her third loan with Maxima for the amount of US$600, to change her husband's motorbike and to raise her pigs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and to raise pigs

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Sorn got married in 1972 and has two children: a son and a daughter. She runs a business weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her sister in 1961 and began her silk production in the same year. She has never attended school while her husband, who is a rice farmer, has not completed primary school. Her daughter lives with her and helps her with weaving silk at home. Her son is married and lives away from the family.

Mrs Sorn is a regular MAXIMA client and has been granted loans from MAXIMA six times previously. She is now requesting a $250 loan to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Doeun

texts.en:
Mrs. P. Doeun (aged 34) and her family live in a small village about 16 kilometers south of Phnom Penh. Mrs Doeun and her husband have been married since 1993 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. All of her children attend school in their village. Mrs Doeun has been selling vegetables and fish in her village for 12 years while her husband has been a construction worker for 5 years.

She is requesting this, her first loan with Maxima, for US$600, to buy vegetables and fish for resale. Mrs Doeun hopes to continue to grow her business so that she can support her children’s studies to the highest possible level and also study languages such as Chinese and English.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and fish for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Eng

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Eng (aged 52) got married in 1979 and has two children: a son and a daughter. She runs a business weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 2004 and began her own silk production in the same year. She and her husband, a farmer and house repairman, have not completed primary school. Eng hopes to make a profit from her business and set up a new loom for her daughter.

Mrs Eng has borrowed money from MAXIMA thrice. She is now requesting a $600 loan to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom, and some funds to help her husband with his rice-growing.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving and growing rice

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Loeng

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Loeng (aged 49) and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River, about 18 kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Mrs S. is a widow and has one daughter. She has been in the business of selling fruit since 2000 and her daughter, Voeun Maly (aged 22) helps her. Mrs S. buys fruit from the market in Phnom Penh and resells them in her village.

She is requesting her third loan with Maxima, for US$350, to expand her business. She and her daughter hope to continue to grow their business so they can create a better life for themselves.

loans.use: To purchase fruit for reselling

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Mrs. B. Thy (aged 25) got married in 2003 and has two daughters. She runs a business weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 2000 and began her own silk production that very year. She did not complete secondary school, while her husband, who rears cows, did not complete primary school. As her daughters are stll toddlers, they stay at home.

This $100 loan is Mrs B.'s first MAXIMA loan. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving.

loans.name: Sayadpary

texts.en: Sayadpary (her son is pictured) is a mother of two children. She is 44 years old and lives in Khachmaz town. She and her son buy hides from the villages to make hats for sale. Now they need a loan of $1200 to buy the necessary materials for making the hats and so increase the number of their clients.

loans.use: To buy the necessary materials for making hats.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Zenfira

texts.en:
Zenfira is single and lives in Khachmaz town. This woman was born in 1969. She buys agricultural products (milk, sour clotted milk, potatoes, cucumbers, peppers, etc.) from the villages and sells them in the market.
Now she needs a loan of $1075 to buy agricultural products. Two years ago she started this business.

loans.use: To buy agricultural products.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Mrs. Judith O., who is a hairdresser, is 54 yrs old, married with 7 children, and lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She learned her business for a year and 6 months, and she opens her own in 2002. She is in need of a loan of $875 to enable her buy more weavon, hair cream and relaxer to sell.

loans.use: To buy more weavon, hair cream and relaxer

loans.name: Queen

texts.en: Mrs. Queen E. is 45 yrs old, married with 6 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells local gin to people living in her community. She has been a LAPO member for 8 years. She is in need of a loan of $525 to enable her buy more local gin for sales, and she promised to repay it in 8 months.

loans.use: To buy more local gin (dry gin)

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mrs. Mary J. is 30 yrs old, married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells clothing and wraps to people living in her community. She needs a loan of $450 to buy more wraps and clothes to sell, and she promised to pay back within 8 months.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sales

loans.name: Tavakkul

texts.en: Tavakkul is 34 years old and lives in Khachmaz town. He is married and has a child. He has six years of experience as a kabab-dealer. This man buys seven or eight sheep to fatten in order to cook kabab. Tavakkul cooks and sells kabab in the market. Now he needs a loan of $725 to buy sheep.

loans.use: To buy sheep for cooking kabab.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Mrs. Ruth A. is 30 yrs old, married with 2 children. She lives in Ehakpen Street in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has a shop and sells clothes in the village market and has been in this business for 7 years. She needs a loan of $525 to buy more clothes to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more gently used clothes to sell

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mrs. Mercy Udoh is 38 yrs old, married with 2 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is a LAPO member, and she sells cloth, tailoring materials, hat materials and other materials. She also makes hat, beads, and sews cloth for people. This is a business started in 1997. She is requesting for a loan of $600 to buy more cloth, hat and tailoring material to sell.

loans.use: To buy more cloth, hat material and other materials

loans.name: Favour

texts.en: Mrs. Favour A., who is in sales of babies' wear, is 30 yrs old, married, with 7 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for 7 years. She needs the sum of the loan of $450 to buy more babies' wear to sell.

loans.use: To buy more baby clothing

loans.name: Yashar

texts.en: Yashar (his brother is pictured) lives in Khachmaz town. He was born in 1982. This single man has been in this business for a year. Yashar needs a loan of $850 to buy foodstuffs for improving his income.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Nazakat

texts.en: Nazakat (her husband is pictured) is a mother of three children. She lives with her family in the Khachmaz region, in the village of Bostanchi. This 49-year-old woman and her husband sell foodstuffs (macaroni, granulated sugar, tea etc.) at retail. She started this business five years ago. Now they need a loan of $850 to buy foodstuffs to increase their income in order to meet the demands of their family.

loans.use: To buy more jewelry and clothes to sell

loans.name: Zenfira

texts.en: Zenfira (her brother is pictured) was born in 1955. She is single and lives in Khachmaz town. Zenfira has run this farming business for a year. Now she needs a loan of $850 to buy fertilizer for improving her farming business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Elmira

texts.en: Elmira (her husband is pictured) is a mother of six children. She was born in 1960. The Aslanov family lives in Khachmaz town.  Her husband has been a taxi driver for four years. Now this family requests a loan of $600 to buy spare parts for improving their business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Khuraman

texts.en: Khuraman (her husband is pictured) is married and has three children. Her family lives in Khachmaz region, in the village of Gusarchay. Khuraman has done orchard farming for two years. Now they need a loan of $850 to buy  fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Bernardina

texts.en:
Bernardina has been working incredibly hard as a “feriante” for the past 8 years. Every single morning, she takes a wide variety of products from the city to the rural countryside of Ayacucho, Perú to sell. Because there are no stores outside the city limits of Ayacucho, the people living there rely on weekly markets for all the food items and other goods they cannot produce themselves. Bernardina has capitalized on this market and everyday she travels to a different location to set up her stand and sell to the communities. She loads her giant wicker basket with fresh fruits and vegetables. She and her husband even bake bread in a rented oven near their home, which she also loads up to sell in the country. 

This type of job is extremely strenuous and tiring. Bernardina wakes up every morning at 4 a.m. and sometimes doesn’t return home until after 8 p.m. However strenuous her vocation, it is necessary, as she is supporting her entire family of 5 children and her husband with her meager income. Years before, Bernardina’s husband also had a job and worked very hard. However, he fell gravely ill and is now unable to perform manual labor. Thus, Bernardina bears the family’s economic burden on her own. She is highly motivated though. She has been saving diligently in order to reach the goal of educating all five of her children in obtaining a university degree. Without the economic help Bernardina has received through her village bank and the support of her family, realization of her dreams would be nearly impossible. Bernardina is requesting a loan of $350. With this money, she will be able to buy larger quantities of fruits and vegetables as well as bake larger quantities of bread.

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of fruits and vegetables as well as bake larger quantities of bread

loans.name: Yegana

texts.en: Yegana is a mother of three children. This young woman was born in 1979. She lives with her family in Khachmaz town. Yegana has sold clothes for three years. Now she requests a loan of $850 to buy clothes.

loans.use: To buy clothes

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Flor María

texts.en:
Flor María is a true businesswoman. Today she owns and runs two stores specializing in beverages, but it took an impressive amount of dedication and initiative to accomplish what she has. Four years ago, Flor María had a small stand selling prepared meals in one of the local markets in Ayacucho, Perú. It was a difficult way to make a living, as the flow of customers was often unreliable due to extremely high rates of competition. In order to improve her economic situation she decided to make a change and open a store specializing in beverages. She supplies all types of sodas and juices, but her big seller is the “cerveza.” Little by little, Flor María store grew and attracted more customers and she was eventually able to open a second store. 

Today, Flor María has hired two “señoritas” who take care of all the sales and customer service, while Flor María handles all the administrative duties for the two stores. She builds relationships with her suppliers, watches her product flow carefully to decide what should be stocked, and everything else that goes along with running a small business. It’s hard work and she always seems to have a million things on her to-do list, but she loves her job.

Flor María’s next goal is to open a third store in Ayacucho. She is an obviously ambitious woman who is constantly looking for ways to bring her business to the next level. This is why she loves her village bank. It has taught her responsibility, punctuality, and how to save money in the bank where it accumulates interest. Moreover, Flor María loves her bank because through it she has made valuable lifelong friendships that serve as a distraction from the difficulties of everyday life. Flor María is requesting a loan of $350. All of this money will be reinvested into her beverage business, with the majority going towards the purchase of spirits, as they are the most popular and the most expensive product she supplies.

loans.use: To purchase spirits, which are both popular and expensive

loans.name: Basti

texts.en: Basti (her husband is pictured) is a mother of six children. She is 54 years old and lives in the Khachmaz region, in the village of Gusarchay. She has six years of experience in this business. Now this family needs a loan of $850 to buy cattle to increase the number of their cattle.

loans.use: To buy cattle

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Bahar

texts.en: Bahar is  a widow and lives in Khachmaz town. She does not have children. This 46-year-old woman has her own shop, where she sells clothes. She has two years of experience in this business. Now she needs a loan of  $850 to buy clothes for improving her business.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Tunzala

texts.en: Tunzala was born in 1974. She lives in Khachmaz town. This woman is married and has two children. She buys clothes and sells them to the shops in the villages. Now she needs a loan of $850 to buy clothes for getting more income. She has been in this business for a year.

loans.use: To buy clothes

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Chingiz

texts.en: Chingiz is a single man and lives in the town of Khudat. He is 37 years old and has been breeding poultry for the past five years. Currently, he purchases chickens and raises them for sale. Now, he needs a loan of $600 to buy additional hens and chickens in order to further increase his income.

loans.use: To purchase hens and chickens

loans.name: Rashad

texts.en: This man lives in Khachmaz town and is single. He was born in 1982. Rashad has sold clothes for two years. Now he needs a loan of  $775 to buy clothes for improving his business.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence B. is a mother of 2 and she is 51 years old. She hails from Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells cooked food and drinks. She has been in this business for the past 6 years and needs a loan of $1200 to buy more drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Fumilola

texts.en: Fumilayo O. is a mother of 3, 43 years of age, and comes from Mebamu, a semi-urban area in Lagos State. She sells kerosene and frozen food. She has been in this business since 2004 and needs a loan of $1200 to buy more kerosene and frozen foods for sale.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene and frozen food for sale

loans.name: Mahsim

texts.en: Mahsim  was born in 1953 and lives in the Khachmaz region, in the village of Gorky. He has three children. He has been breeding cattle for 10 years. Now he requests a loan of $725 to buy cattle.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary B. is a seamstress; she sews all kinds of dresses. She specializes in sewing female clothing. She is married with two children ages 12 and 10. Her husband is a taxi driver whose daily income is not enough to meet the needs of the family. To help with the family finances, Mary works very hard.

Her existing sewing machine is giving her problems, she is therefore asking for $1,200 to buy a new sewing machine and other sewing materials to meet the demand of her customers.

loans.use: Buy a new sewing machine and other sewing materials

loans.name: Bola

texts.en: Bola A. is a single parent (she is a widow). She comes from Okiafa in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 48 years of age and a mother of 5. She sells provisions and operates a business center. She has been in business since 1983 and needs a loan of $1200 to buy computer and a photocopier. This, she said, will help her serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy a computer and photocopier

loans.name: Sahhat

texts.en: Sahhat was born in 1976 and lives in the Khachmaz region. He is single. This man started this business 3 years ago. Currently, he buys cattle and fattens them for sale. Now, he needs a loan of $850 to buy additional cattle in order to further increase his income.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
In the middle of the “Jesus de Nazarenas” Market in Ayacucho, Peru, one can find Gladys behind her large condiments stand, surrounded by colorful sauces and spices. Located directly in front of the butcher section, she is in the perfect place to sell her products. Gladys prepares the condiments daily in her home very early in the morning. She packs these up in tupperware containers and brings it to her stand. She makes ground garlic, red, yellow, and green chili sauces, boiled potatoes, and several additional types of condiments used daily in almost every Ayacuchan household.
