She also sells other types of ingredients such as milk, butter, cheese, crackers, soy sauce, etc. This is a very common and very convenient type of stand found in a number of the large farmers markets within Peru.

For example, a mother shopping in preparation for the large daily meal at noon can stop by the butcher’s section and order a supply of fresh meat. From there, she can turn around to Gladys, tell her that she will be preparing a beef dish. With this information, Gladys takes a small plastic bag and fills it with a complex mixture of the different types of her condiments to customize the perfect beef seasoning.

Gladys knows exactly how helpful her stand is for her busy customers who are taking care of their children and their homes and also need to prepare a large meal for several hungry mouths. Seven years ago, just before she decided to open up a stand in the market, Gladys was a housewife raising 3 children while her husband worked. When her children grew older, she found she had free time and decided to supplement her husband’s modest income.

One day, Gladys would love to open a grocery store from her home. She is also financing the education of all three of her children. One daughter is studying obstetrics, one is just about to enter the university, and the last is still in middle school. There are many reasons Gladys is motivated to expand her business and save money. This is why she is so glad to have been a part of her village bank for the past 7 years. It was through the bank that she has learned about punctuality and responsibility, two values essential to running a successful business. She is currently requesting a loan of $350. With this money she will stock up on all of her most popular products and the ingredients that go into her freshly prepared condiments.

loans.use: To stock up on her most popular products and the ingredients that go into her freshly prepared condiments.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more merchandise to meet client demand

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia I. is a mother of 6, 35 years of age, and hails from Okoko in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells clothes and also sews clothes for people. She has been in this business since 1992. She needs a loan of $1200 to enable her buy more clothes to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Iris

texts.en:
Iris has an eye for fashion and has found the perfect way to turn this talent into a business. Because her home city of Ayacucho, Perú is located rather remotely in the Andes Mountains, it is difficult to find a variety of clothing and jewelry. For this reason, Iris makes the monthly ten hour bus trip to the capital city of Lima to buy beautiful clothing and jewelry which she carries home to Ayacucho and sells to friends, family, and customers. Much of the time she receives orders, for example for a summer sundress, and with this direction she uses her good taste to pick out a nice outfit. 

Iris has been involved in this business for the past 10 years, and is very content. The way she currently does business allows her much freedom and the ability her to travel, an aspect she loves. She is currently entering the busiest time of year. In Ayacucho, at the end of the school year (which is in January), there are many graduation parties. From those completing primary school to high school graduations, families celebrate this happy occasion. A staple of these parties is the perfect graduation dress. Beginning in December, orders begin pouring to Iris from mothers wanting the perfect graduation dress for their daughters. Thus, Iris is planning a special weeklong trip to Lima in December, when she will buy many dresses to bring back to Ayacucho. An economic boost in the form of a small loan is what makes projects such as this possible for Iris. It is also what has made the support of her family of four daughters possible. Without such loans, the growth and success of her small enterprising business would be nearly impossible. This is why Iris loves her village bank. It is there that she receives advice on everything from saving her money to how to better support her family. Iris is currently requesting a loan of $1025 in order to fill the many orders pouring in for the holiday and graduation season.

loans.use: To buy dresses, jewelry, and gifts

loans.name: Chjioma

texts.en: Chioma A. is a mother of 3, 35 years of age, and hails from Lagos State. She sells drugs and provisions in her pharmacy. She has been in her business since the year 2002 and needs a loan of $875 to buy more drugs and provisions to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy drugs (pharmaceuticals) and provisions to sell.

loans.name: Rosa Teodora

texts.en:
Since she was 11 years old, Rosa has been in the “artesanía” business. She specializes in the purchase and sale of “tejidos,” which are beautifully woven and embroidered works of art, typical to Peru and especially her home region of Ayacucho. Rosa’s older sister is a talented weaver, and when Rosa was a young girl, she would take her sister’s tapestries into the city center to sell. Over the years, Rosa used her knowledge of tapestry sales to create a thriving business. Today, she has her own stand in the biggest market in Ayacuho, Peru, where she sells all types of hand woven pieces shipped from all over the country. The majority of artesanías come from Cusco, but she also sells goods that come from Bolivia. She also sells goods that are made right in her home town of Ayacucho, which she contracts by traveling from weaver to weaver, soliciting partnerships. 

Rosa has been selling from her stand in the local market for the past 15 years. Her goal is to look for ways to move forward and progress, growing her business to its full potential. She has been earning profits and saving her money diligently. Currently, she is saving her money to buy a computer for the oldest of her four children. He is 22 years old and studying at the local university. Education is very important to Rosa and she is very happy to be able to provide such opportunities for her children. 

Rosa says she is extremely happy with her local bank. As she can be very shy, she was nervous at first to attend the weekly meetings. However, it didn’t take long before she made lifelong friendships and she now feels as though she has a second family. The bank has also provided her with immense economic assistance. Without such economic advantages, growing her business would be extremely difficult. Rosa is currently requesting a loan of $500. With this money, she will be able to buy greater quantities of woven goods to sell to clients.

loans.use: To buy greater quantities of woven goods to sell to clients

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more merchandise at wholesale prices

loans.name: Sady Yanina

texts.en:
Sady leads a very busy life as a “feriante.” Constantly traveling back and forth between the city and rural countryside, she buys and sells a wide assortment of products. The majority of these products are clothes, such as jackets and blouses, which are purchased in the city and sold in the country.  There are no stores of any kind in the country, leaving the rural populations to depend on feriantes like Sady for all their purchases. This is why, every single day, Sady makes the 2 hour trip to the country with a large load of clothing. She carries mostly smaller items such as blouses and skirts because it allows her to carry much larger quantities, which allows her to sell to a much larger client base.

For the past 2 years, Sady has been involved in the “feriante” business. Her mother is involved in the same trade, buying and selling a special type of colorful skirt, traditional to Ayacucho, Peru. Sady passionately explains that the motivation to continue working so hard everyday in such an incredibly tiring profession comes from her two children. She diligently saves her money in the bank in anticipation of funding the education of her 1 and 4 year old all the way through university. Education is the most important gift Sady could possibly give to her sons, she explains, and the only way to surpass poverty in the long run. Professionally, Sady is working towards opening a clothing store in the city of Ayacucho. This has been a dream of hers for some time now and would allow her to travel less and spend more time with her children as they grow up. 

Sady has been involved in her village bank for the past 2 years, ever since she was invited by her mother, who has been taking out loans from there for more than 10 years. Apart from the huge economic help the bank has provided, she loves the knowledge she has gained from the weekly classes and all the friendships she has made. Sady is currently requesting a loan of $300. With this money she will buy even larger quantities of clothing to sell, allowing her to generating a larger client base and ultimately a larger profit.

loans.use: To buy even larger quantities of clothing to sell

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin A. is happily married with 4 children. She is 38 years of age and comes from a semi-urban area in Lagos state, Nigeria. She sells provisions and foodstuffs.She has been in this business since 2003 and needs a loan of $875 to buy more provision and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: To buy provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Mrs. Patience A. is 40 years old, married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells tailoring materials and cloth. This is a business she started in 1999. She is requesting a loan of $450 to buy more cloth and tailoring material to sell.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring (sewing) materials and cloth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To diversify his merchandise and buy essential products in bulk

loans.name: Blanca Aurora

texts.en:
La señora Blanca pertenece al Banco Comunal “María Montesori”, vive en Jr. Raymondi 1034, del distrito Calleria, departamento de  Ucayali. Tiene 44 años de edad y es madre de 1 hijo, está separada y el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos de su familia, es así que Blanca Aurora, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 (US$ 100.00) decide invertir en venta de comida  a domicilio.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de comida, negocio ubicado al costado de la tienda que tiene su hermana Mariluz, en donde llega muy temprano para atender a sus clientes con desayunos y almuerzos que son de gran acogida y gustan a todos.  Paralelamente,  por las tardes se dedica a la venta de ropa a domicilio, cuenta con un gran número de clientes que saben de su buen gusto en lo referente a ropas y están a la expectativa de las novedades que les pueda ofrecer.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,500 (US$ 502.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 3 kilos de arroz, 1 kilo de azúcar, 3 paquetes de sal, carnes de res y 5 pollos (aves para consumo), además ampliará el local donde actualmente esta atendiendo.

Blanca está muy contenta por pertenecer a Manuela Ramos, nos ha dicho que le cambio la vida y esta feliz porque ve los resultados de su inversión y espera y ruega al señor que todo le vaya bien y que no le falte salud para ella y su hijo.

loans.use: Compra de insumos.  Ampliación de local comercial.

loans.name: Blanca Aurora

texts.es:
Mrs. Blanca belongs to the communal bank “María Montesori.” She lives at 1031 Jr. Raymondi in the Calleria district of the department of Ucayali. She is 44 years old and is the mother of one son. She is separated from her husband, and that income does not cover the expenses of the family. That’s why Blanca Aurora, with her first loan from Manuela Ramos of $100 (S/.300), decided to invest in selling food out of her home.

Currently, she sells her food at a business located alongside the store that her sister, Mariluz, runs. She arrives very early to serve her customers breakfasts and lunches that are warmly received and well-liked by all. Additionally, in the afternoons she devotes herself to selling clothing door-to-door. She counts on a large number of customers that know her good taste in clothing and eagerly await the novelties that she can offer them.

With this loan from Manuela Ramos, which she will repay in four months, she will purchase 3 kilos of rice, 1 kilo of sugar, 3 packets of salt, beef, and five chickens. Additionally, she will expand her current location.

Blanca is very pleased to belong to Manuela Ramos; she has told us that it changed her life, and she is happy because she sees the results of her investment. She hopes and prays that everything will go well and that she and her son will stay healthy.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Blanca pertenece al Banco Comunal “María Montesori”, vive en Jr. Raymondi 1034, del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 44 años de edad y es madre de 1 hijo, está separada y el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos de su familia, es así que Blanca Aurora, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 (US$ 100.00) decide invertir en venta de comida a domicilio.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de comida, negocio ubicado al costado de la tienda que tiene su hermana Mariluz, en donde llega muy temprano para atender a sus clientes con desayunos y almuerzos que son de gran acogida y gustan a todos. Paralelamente, por las tardes se dedica a la venta de ropa a domicilio, cuenta con un gran número de clientes que saben de su buen gusto en lo referente a ropas y están a la expectativa de las novedades que les pueda ofrecer.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 3 kilos de arroz, 1 kilo de azúcar, 3 paquetes de sal, carnes de res y 5 pollos (aves para consumo), además ampliará el local donde actualmente esta atendiendo.

Blanca está muy contenta por pertenecer a Manuela Ramos, nos ha dicho que le cambio la vida y esta feliz porque ve los resultados de su inversión y espera y ruega al señor que todo le vaya bien y que no le falte salud para ella y su hijo.

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs. Expansion of her retail location

loans.name: Blanca Juliana

texts.es:
Blanca is a member of the Comunal Bank “La Familia”, and lives at 2381 Yarina Avenue in the Yarina Cocha district, department of Ucayali. She is 29 years old and is the mother of three children whom she adores. She is separated, and her small income doesn’t cover the household expenses. With her first loan of 300 soles (US $100) from Manuela Ramos, Blanca decided to begin selling toys, clothes, shoes, and braids and tassels for drapes and upholstry.

She is currently selling toys from her home, where she attends her clients all day. She wakes up very early to take care of her young children and drop them off at school, and then she returns home to attend to her business, as her products are already popular.

With this loan of 1,500 soles (approximately US $502), which she will repay in 4 months, she will increase the variety of her products with the purchase of 3 dozen toys. She will also take advantage of the approaching Christmas season and will buy 50 Christmas decorations.

Blanca feels very calm and has a great desire to keep working at her business in order to make it grow, as well as realize one of her dreams, to have a happy family that she can watch progress and succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Blanca pertenece al Banco Comunal La Familia, vive en la Av. Yarina 2381, del distrito Yarina Cocha, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 29 años D. edad y es madre D. 3 hijos que son su adoración, está separada y sus pocos ingreso no alcanza para los gastos en casa, es así que Blanca, con el primer préstamo D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300.00 (US$100.00) deciD. invertir en la venta D. juguetes, ropa, zapatos y artículos D. pasamanería.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta D. juguetes, su negocio se ubica en su misma casa, donD. atienD. todo el día. Se levanta muy temprano para atender a sus pequeños hijos y dejarlos en la escuela, luego se dirige a su negocio para atender a sus clientes, ya que sus productos tienen una buena aceptación.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 1,500 (US$ 502.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, incrementará su variedad D. productos con la compra D. 3 docenas D. juguetes, aprovechando que se acerca las fiestas naviD.ñas, también comprará medio ciento D. adornos naviD.ños.

Blanca se siente muy tranquila y con muchas ganas D. seguir trabajando en su negocio para que éste crezca y pueda realizar algunos sueños que tiene, su familia está feliz D. verla progresar y salir adelante.

loans.use: Buy toys and Christmas decorations

loans.name: Ericka

texts.es:
Ericka belongs to the communal bank “La Familia.” She lives at 520 Jr. Atahualpa in the Calleria district in the department of Ucayali. She is 28 years old and has one young son. Her husband works selling motorcycle parts, but his income is not enough to cover the household expenses. With her first loan of $100 (S./300.00) from Manuela Ramo, Ericka decided to invest in tires and motorcycle parts.

Currently, she has a motorcycle parts sales shop that she works in all day. She gets up very early to tend to her young son, prepares breakfast, then goes to work at her store.

With this loan from Manual Ramos of about $669 (S/.2000), which she will pay back in four months, she will increase her merchandise with the purchase of a dozen tires, 25 units of motor oil, 2 packages of parts, and other supplies.

Ericka is very happy with all aspects of her life. Her business grows a little everyday, and it is frequently visited by motorcycle drivers that are able to find what they need there. Additionally, she has the unconditional support of her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Ericka pertenece al Banco Comunal La Familia, vive en Jr. Atahualpa 520, del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 28 años de edad y es madre de 1 hijo que aun es pequeño, su esposo se dedica a la venta de repuestos de motos, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para solventar los gastos de su casa, es así que Ericka, con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/.300.00 (US$100.00) decide invertir en llantas y repuestos de motos.

En la actualidad cuenta con una tienda de venta de repuestos de motos, donde atiende todo el día, se levanta muy temprano para atender a su pequeño hijo, prepara el desayuno y luego se va atender su negocio.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 2.000 (US$ 669.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, incrementará sus productos con la compra de1 docena de llantas, 25 unidades de aceite de motos y motokar, 2 paquetes de repuestos, etc.

Ericka se siente muy feliz en todos los aspectos de su vida, su negocio crece cada día mas, es muy concurrido por motocarristas que ahí encuentran lo que necesitan, además cuenta con el apoyo incondicional de su esposo.

loans.use: Purchase of parts and tires for motorcycles and motorcars.

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es:
María belongs to the communal bank "La Familia" (The Family). She lives in Jr. Lago Titcaca 139, in Calleria district in Ucayali. She is 52-years-old. Her husband is a mechanic, and they have 4 children who are adults. They help with the business when they can. Some of them work and contribute to the family income, but it still isn't enough. This is why María decided to open a small grocery store thanks to the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 nuevos soles ($100.)

Now her grocery store is well-stocked. She sells bread, sugar, rice, eggs, toothpaste, etc. She gets up very early to do her domestic chores, then goes to attend to her store where she feels very happy conversing with her clients and providing for their needs.

With the recent loan from Manuela Ramos of 2,000 nuevos soles ($669), which will be repaid in 4 months, she purchased 3 packages of soft drinks (small and large), ice cream, 2 bags of sugar, 1 bag of rice, 2 bags of salt, 1 container of eggs, 2 boxes of milk, etc.

María Luisa told us that she feels like a very lucky woman because thanks to Manuela Ramos, she will be able to expand her business and increase her income. She will have the opportunity to accomplish some things that she had to postpone before for economic reasons, and this will give well-being to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Maria pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Familia”, vive en Jr. Lago Titicaca 139, del distrito Calleria, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 52 años D. edad, su esposo es mecánico y es madre D. 4 hijos que ya son mayores D. edad y que la ayudan en el negocio cuando les es posible. Algunos trabajan. y aportan en el hogar, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza, por ese motivo María decidió poner una bodega gracias al primer préstamo D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300.00 (US$100.00).

En la actualidad tiene su bodega bien surtida, donD. venD. pan, azúcar, arroz, huevos, pasta dental, etc. Ella se levanta muy temprano para atender los quehaceres domésticos, y después se va a atender su bodega donD. se siente muy a gusto conversando con sus clientes y satisfaciendo sus necesidades.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 2,000 (US$ 669.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, compró D. 3 paquetes D. bebidas gaseosas (grandes y chicas), helados, 2 sacos D. azúcar, 1 saco D. arroz, 2 sacos D. sal, golosinas, 1 jaba D. huevos, 2 cajas D. leche, etc.

Maria Luisa nos dijo que se siente una mujer muy dichosa porque gracias a Manuela Ramos ella podrá ampliar su negocio e incrementara sus ingresos y tendrá oportunidad D. poder realizar algunas cosas que antes estuvo postergando por motivos económicos y que le dará bienestar familiar.

loans.use: Purchase of various products for a grocery store

loans.name: Maria Magdalena's Group

texts.es:
Maria Magdalena and Maximilian are friends and they have the same profession, they are university trained midwives and members of Bank Yachay Wasi which means “house of knowledge” in Quechua. Maximiliana also sells Renaware kitchen utensils and Maria Magdalena has three businesses, selling cosmetic products, selling health products, and the production of apple vinegar. Maria Magdalena has been a member of the Communal Bank for 8 years of which she has served on the board on various occasions. Maximiliana has been a part of the Communal Bank for 4 years and what she enjoys the most is the fraternity and sense of belonging that has formed between the female members. She also encouraged the other members to save more and a make a Christmas basket for each one of them. Their loans are for $225 and $100 respectively, and will be used for the purchase of cosmetics, supplies for the production of apple vinegar, pots, and kettles. They dream of owning a pretty house, having an independent business, and growing and expanding their current business. At Finca they learned to share, practiced basic finance, and saved.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva volunteer.

Maria Magdalena y Maximiliana son amigas y tienen la misma profesión, ellas son Obstetrices y son socias del Banco Yachay Wasi que significa casa del saber en Quechua. Maximiliana es vendedora D. una línea D. utensilios D. cocina llamada Renaware y Maria Magdalena tiene tres negocios, venta D. cosméticos, productos para la salud y elaboración D. vinagre D. manzana. Maria Magdalena está 8 años en el Banco Comunal y durante este tiempo ella fue parte D. la junta directiva en varias ocasiones. Por otro lado Maximiliana está 4 años en el Banco Comunal y lo que más le gusta es la confraternidad y la integración que se fomenta entre las socias. Además motivo a su grupo para ahorrar más y hacer una canasta en navidad para cada una. Sus préstamos D. 225 y 100 USD respectivamente y lo invertirán en la compra D. cosméticos, insumos para la elaboración del vinagre D. manzana, ollas y teteras. Ellas sueñan con tener una casa bonita, tener un negocio independiente, ampliar y hacer crecer su negocio. En Finca aprendieron a compartir, practicar los valores y ahorrar.

loans.use: Their loans for $225 and $100 respectively will be used for the purchase of cosmetics, supplies for the production of apple vinegar, pots, and kettles.

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.es:
Guadalupe J. has run her own business for 26 years. For 25 years she sold fruit and vegetables at the Terminal Market in Guatemala City but a rent increase forced her to relocate and open a shop out of her home on the outskirts of town in an area called Villa Lobos II in Villa Nueva. She is very entrepreneurial and she works hard to succeed in a difficult economic environment, rising early each morning and tending the shop for more than 12 hours. Despite facing quite a bit of competition locally, Guadalupe struggles to prove that a dedicated and hard-working mother can support her four children.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Guadalupe J., inicio hace 26 años su negocio propio, el cual consiste en una pequeña venta de frutas y verduras en el mercado denominado La Terminal, ubicado en la ciudad de Guatemala. Alli estubo durante 25 años. En la actualidad, su nogocio lo traslado a su casa, ubicada en una area urbano marginal, denominada Villa Lobos II, Villa Nueva, debido a que tenia altos gastos de alquiler en el mercado La Terminal. La Señora Guadalupe J. es una persona emprendedora, que a pesar de lo dificil de su situacion economica y social, debido al sector donde vive, ella sigue trabajando y superandose cada dia. Todos los dias ella abre su negocio desde muy temprano de la mañana, y lo cierra ya entrada la noche, su horario de trabajo es de mas de 12 horas diarias. En la venta de su negocio, ella tiene bastante competencia, no obstante es el medio por el cual ella se gana la vida y el sustento de sus cuatro hijos, gracias a sus esfuerzo y deseos de superacion. Ella es un ejemplo de que con esfuerzo y dedicacion se puede salir adelante.

loans.use: To stock a general store.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FAPE - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es:
Silvia belongs to the Communal Bank Teresa Ramos, she lives in Jr. 28 D. Julio 302, Yarina Cocha district, Ucayali state. She is 51 years old and mother of two small children who depend on her. She is married, her husband is a farmer, but the income doesn't meet the family expenses and for this reason Silvia, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos for 300 Soles (US$100.00) she decided to open a small store that sells soda pop and candy.

Today she has her soda pop store, which she attends to with great care and dedication. They get up at 4:00 am to open the business and then at 6:00 am she prepares breakfast for her children in order to then be able to attend to the store. Her children are small and depend on her, in all the ways children can depend on a mother.

With the recent loan received from Manuela Ramos for 2000 Soles (approximately US$669.00), which will be paid in 4 monthes, she will expand and buy a greater quantity of products, like 6 packages of large soda pop, 6 packages of small soda pop, 30 cases of beer, 100 Soles in candy and the rest in the construction of the floor of her locale.

Silvia is very content, because she sees that her business is well-received by her customers. Her dreams are coming true thanks to her effort and great care.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Silvia pertenece al Banco Comunal “Teresa Ramos”, vive en Jr. 28 D. Julio 302, del distrito D. Yarina Cocha del departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 51 años y es madre D. 2 hijos menores D. edad que dependen aun D. ella, está casada, su esposo es agricultor, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos familiares, por esa razón Silvia, con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300.00 (US$100.00) deciD. poner una pequeña tienda D. venta D. bebidas gaseosas y golosinas.

En la actualidad cuenta con una tienda D. venta D. gaseosas, la misma que atienD. con mucho esmero y dedicación. Se levantan a las 4.00 am. para abrir su negocio y luego a las 6.00 am. prepara el desayuno D. sus pequeños hijos para después poder atender la tienda. Sus hijos aun son pequeños y dependen D. ella, en todos los aspectos en los que se pueda depender D. una madre.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 2,000 (US$ 669.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, ampliará y comprará mayor cantidad D. productos, como 6 paquetes D. gaseosas grandes, 6 paquetes D. gaseosas chicas, 30 cajas D. cerveza, S/. 100.00 en golosinas y el resto en la construcción del piso D. su cochera (lugar donD. tiene ubicado su negocio).

Silvia está muy contenta, porque ve que su negocio tiene cada vez mayor acogida por sus clientes. Sus sueños se están realizando gracias a su propio esfuerzo y esmero.

loans.use: Purchase soda pop at wholesale prices, purchase candy, maintain the locale.

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
Francisca belongs to the Teresa Ramos community bank and lives in the district of Calleria, department of Ucayali. She is 44 and the mother of 3 children, all of them adults. Because she is a widow with limited income, with her first loan from Manuel Ramos she put up a small soft drink stand.

She still has that stand, which she attends to along with her children and her daughter-in-law. They all rise very early to take care of the business; although her older children are now economically independent they have never forgotten the great sacrifice their mother maD. for them.

With a loan from Manuel Ramos, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy a greater amount of products for her soft drink stand, such as 20 cases of carbonated drinks and candy in bulk. Additionally she will expand her stand, for which she will need 2 cords of lumber, 10 calamine plates, 4 cans of paint and 3 kilos of nails.

Francisca is very content to see her business growing and feels that her dreams are coming true without having to depend on others.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Francisca pertenece al banco comunal Teresa Ramos, vive en Jr. Eduardo del Águila 689, del Distrito D. Calleria del departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 44 años y es madre D. 3 hijos, todos mayores D. edad, es viuda, por lo que el ingreso que tiene no alcanza, es así que Francisca, con el primer préstamo que recibió D. Manuela Ramos deciD. poner una pequeña fuente D. soda.

En la actualidad cuenta con dicha fuente D. soda, la misma que atienD. junto a sus hijos, y su nuera, se levantan muy temprano para atender el negocio, sus hijos mayores ya se independizaron económicamente pero nunca olvidan el gran sacrificio que hizo su madre por ellos.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará mayor cantidad D. productos para su fuente D. soda para lo cual, invertirá en 20 cajas D. bebidas gaseosas, golosinas al por mayor, además ampliará su local, para ello necesita 2 cientos D. madera, 10 planchas D. calaminas, 4 baldes D. pintura, y 3 kg. D. clavos.

Francisca está muy contenta porque ve que su negocio prospera y siente que sus sueños se están realizando sin la necesidad D. depender D. otras personas.

loans.use: Purchase of soft drinks and candy for resale. Expansion and maintenance of commercial premises.

loans.name: Justo Rufino

texts.es:
Justo Rufino P. has been a small business owner for more than thirty years.  He has two shops selling clothing in busy parts of Guatemala City.  He is very hard working and rises early each morning to tend one of the shops while one of his sons tends the other.  With income from the two shops he supports his wife and four children.  This is a busy time of year for clothing sales and Justo wants to increase the quantity and quality of his inventory.    Translated by a Kiva volunteer.  


El señor Justo Rufino P.,  es un micro comerciante guatemalteco, que por mas de 30 años, se ha
dedicado a la venta de ropa nueva, en la actualidad tiene dos puestos de venta, los dos ubicadados en areas populares de la ciudad capital de Guatemala.

Todos los dias desde muy temprano por las mañanas,  deja a uno de sus cuatro hijos en uno de los dos puestos de venta, y el se va al otro puesto de venta que tiene.

El señor Justo Rufino P., es una persona muy trabajadora.

En la actualidad sus ventas se han incrementado por la epoca de fin de año, y el desea mejorar considerablemente, gracias a su dedicacion y esfuerzo.

Con los ingresos de sus dos locales comerciales y de sus ventas, el mantiene a sus esposa y a sus 4 hijos.

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FAPE - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Lina Alicia

texts.es:
Lina belongs to the community bank "Las Colinas", and lives in the district of Calleria, department of Ucayali. She is 52 years old, separated and the mother of 2 grown children, who admire their mother very much for the sacrifices she maD. to raise them. Her income was not enough to cover household expenses, so Lina, with her first loan from Manuel Ramos, decided to invest in the purchase and sale of shoes which she herself makes, baby clothing, decorations, etc.

Currently she sells clothing, towels, decorations and toys for the Christmas season. Her business is located in her home, where her clients come to buy products because they trust her good taste in the shoes, decorations and clothing she sells.

With a loan from Manuela Ramos, which will be paid in 4 months, she will buy 1 kilo of fabric, 30 pairs of shoes, material for decorating shoes and clothing, 2 dozen children´s toys and 1 dozen sheets (bed clothing).

Lina is very pleased to share her experience with other women, to tell them not be afraid to start up a business by themselves, as women as very capable and enterpreneurial. She encourages women to approach the Manuela Ramos organization and feels very content and happy for what she has achieved.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Lina pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Colinas”, vive en Jr. C. Calvo Araujo 778, del distrito Calleria, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 52 años D. edad, está separada y es madre 2 hijos que ya son mayores D. edad y que admiran mucho a su mama por el sacrificio que hizo para criarlos, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para sus gastos familiares, es así que Lina, con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos deciD. invertir en la compra y venta D. zapatos que ella misma confecciona, ropa D. bebes, adornos, etc.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta D. ropa, toallas, adornos y juguetes para fiestas naviD.ñas, su negocio está ubicado en su misma casa, donD. llegan sus clientas para adquirir sus productos ya que confían en el buen gusto que tiene Lina en la confección D. sus zapatos y así mismo con los adornos y ropa que venD..

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 1 kilo telas, 30 pares zapatos, 1 ciento D. materiales para adornar los zapatos y vestidos, 2 docenas D. juguetes para niños y 1 docena D. sabanas (ropa D. cama).

Lina nos esperó muy ansiosa y contenta porque quería compartir su experiencia con las demás mujeres y decirles que no tengan miedo a poner un negocio solas, que las mujeres somos muy capaces y emprendedoras y que nos acerquemos sin dudar a la institución D. Manuela Ramos , donD. Lina se siente muy contenta y feliz por los logros obtenidos.

loans.use: Purchase of fabric, shoes, toys, and bed clothing (sheets).

loans.name: Lola

texts.es:
Lola belongs to the Community Bank "La Familia", and lives in the district of Calleria, department of Ucayali. She is 54, a single mother to one son, who she adores and who is the most valuable thing God has granted her. Her income was not enough, however, so Lola, with her first loan from Manuela Ramos, decided to invest in the purchase of toys for the Christmas holidays, Christmas decorations and clothing for women and men.

She currently sells clothing and accessories for Christmas decorations from her home, where her clients come to buy products since they trust her good taste in what she sells.

With a loan from Manuel Ramos, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy clothing for men, women and children, as well as save part of it for an emergency. As she says...a cautious woman is worth twice as much.

Lola is very content to be part of Manuel Ramos and very grateful for the advice and guidance she received from them. They have been great friends and guides who have known how to teach her well.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Lola pertenece al Banco Comunal “La Familia”, vive en Jr. Alfredo Eglinton 171, del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 54 años de edad y es madre soltera, tiene 1 hijo que es su vida y su adoración, lo más valioso que Dios le dio en esta vida, pero el ingreso que tiene no le alcanza, es así que Lola, con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos decidió invertir en la compra de juegos para fiestas navideñas, adornos navideños y en ropa para damas y caballeros.

En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de ropa y accesorios para decoraciones navideñas en su misma casa, donde llegan sus clientas para adquirir sus productos ya que confían en el buen gusto que tiene Lola con sus productos.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará ropa al por mayor (para damas, caballeros y niños), además tiene la costumbre de ahorrar para alguna emergencia que pueda presentarse, ella dice que........ mujer cauta vale por dos.

Lola está muy contenta por pertenecer a Manuela Ramos, además agradecida de los consejos y la asesoría que recibió de sus promotoras de crédito, las que fueron grandes amigas y guías que supieron orientarla bien.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing for resale.

loans.name: Loty

texts.es:
Loty belongs to the Communal Bank Luz y Paz, from AA. HH. Ivan Sickick Mz. A Lt. 06, Manantay District, Ucayali state. She is 33 years old and mother of 2 young daughters who depend on her. She is married, her husband is a motocycle-taxi driver, but the income doesn't meet their expenses, so Loty, with the first loan from Manuela Ramos for 300 Soles (US$100.00) she decided to open a small clothing and lingerie workshop.

Today she has a small sewing shop, which she attends to with great care and dedication. She takes her small daughters to school very early and then takes care of her shop, her daughters are still young and depend on her.

With the recent loan from Manuela Ramos for 1200 Soles (approximately US$401), which will be repaid in 4 months, she will expand and buy products in bulk, such as 4 tubes of elastic, 6 reels of thread, 230 Soles in wholesale fabric, 20 Soles in accessories, 200 soles in the maintenance of their motorcar and for transportation cost to purchase the merchandise.

Loty is very happy because she sees that her clothing shop is growing and the sales of her products growing, and that her dreams are coming true thanks to the support Manuela Ramos is giving her.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Loty pertenece al banco comunal Luz y Paz, del AA. HH. Ivan Sickick Mz. A Lt. 06, del Distrito de Manantay del departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 33 años y es madre de 2 hijas menores de edad que dependen aun de ella, estás casada, su esposo es motocarrista, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza, es así que Loty, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decide poner un pequeño taller de confección de ropa y lencería.

En la actualidad cuenta con un pequeño taller de costura, la misma que atiende con mucho esmero y dedicación, muy temprano lleva a sus pequeñas hijas a la escuela para después poder atender su taller, sus hijas aun son pequeñas y dependen de ella.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,200 (US$ 401.00) aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, ampliará y comprará mayor cantidad de productos, como 4 tubos de elásticos, 6 carretes de hilo, S/. 230.00 en telas al por mayor, S/. 20.00 en adornos, S/. 200.00 en el mantenimiento de su motocar y para gastos de movilidad para compra la mercadería.

Loty está muy contenta porque ve que su taller de ropa crece y la venta de sus productos aumenta, y que sus sueños se están realizando gracias al apoyo que Manuela Ramos le esta dando.

loans.use: Purchase thread, fabric, elastic at wholesale prices, maintain the motorcar.

loans.name: Mariluz

texts.es:
Av. Saenz Peña 414, Calleria district, Ucayali department. She is 50 years old and is mother to two children. Her husband is a lathe operator, but with his income it is enough for their household expenses, so Mariluz, with the first loan from Manuela Ramos for S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decided to start a store to buy motorcycle parts and oil changes.

Currently, her store is located downtown, in a zone with much traffic which suits her business well, and she gets more customers with her offer of a free oil change when they buy the oil.

With the recent loan received from Manuela Ramos for S/. 1,300 (US$ 435.00 approx.), which will be paid in 4 months, she will equip her business with some necessary products and buy 500 rodajes , 100 arms, bolts of different sizes, and glues. In addition, they need to expand their locale.

Mariluz is very happy to have obtained said loan, because her business is growing and so is the wellbeing of her family too, and this is why she is thankful and happy that Manuela Ramos has come to her life.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Mariluz pertenece al Banco Comunal María Montesori, vive en la Av. Sáenz Peña 414, del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 50 años de edad y es madre de 2 hijos, su espose es tornero, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos familiares, es así que Mariluz, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decide poner una tienda de venta de repuesto de motos y cambio de aceites.

En la actualidad tiene su tienda que esta ubicada en el centro de la ciudad, en una zona muy concurrida que le favorece para su negocio, y capta más clientes con su promoción de cambio de aceites gratis por la compra del mismo producto.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,300 (US$ 435..00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, equipará su negocio con algunos productos necesarios y comprará 500 rodajes, 100 brazos, pernos de diversos tamaños y pegamentos, además necesita ampliar su local

Mariluz está muy contenta por haber obtenido dicho préstamo, ya que su negocio crece y el bienestar de su familia también, y por es está muy agradecida y feliz de que Manuela Ramos haya llegado a su vida.

loans.use: Buying spare parts. Expanding business locale. (Compra de repuestos.  Ampliación de local comercial.)

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 34 years of age, a self-employed tailor. She is married to her husband Martin, with whom she has four children: Sarah, 12 years; Charles, 6; Tony, 2 and a half; and a baby of three months. After her primary school, Ruth’s mother couldn’t raise tuition fees for secondary/higher education. Ruth’s mother resorted to taking her daughter to a technical school where she was trained in dressmaking.

Ruth and Martin bought a used manual sewing machine from an old tailor (woman) from their savings after a period of time. She established the sewing business in 2001, sewing children’s clothing and marketing them. She purchases material from the city centre, crafts different designs at home in Nansana, a city suburb, and makes her sales in bulk to the vendors in Owino Market, the largest local market in Uganda. She says sometimes local citizens place orders to design and craft clothing.

The overhead has been low, and she has managed to break even. Ruth believes there is a future for the business since sewing is done at home with limited costs. She would like to borrow $ 500 to purchase another sewing machine (second-hand) and materials (cloth) that will be repaid in six months. With time, she will use her profits to meet basic household needs, tuition fees for her family, and pass on the skills to her children as she has already done to the elder daughter, Sarah.

loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine and material

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 38 years of age. He is married to his wife with whom he has five children, three girls and two boys, all at school. Peter is one of seven children in his family. His father died when they were still young but the mother somehow found money to pay for Peter’s primary education. He was born in the eastern part of Uganda and he came to be employed in Kampala. He deals in a motorcycle-transport business in Wandegeya (a Kampala suburb) and he has experience of over seven years. At the moment he owns one motorcycle which is depreciating.

He has been saving some money that he would like to top up with a Kiva loan to purchase a second new motorcycle for the same business. He would like to borrow $800 to top up his long time savings to purchase another motorcycle and he will pay back the loan in six months. With time, he will use his profits to meet basic household needs, tuition fees for his family, and set up a retail shop that will be run by his elder daughter.

loans.use: Purchase of a new motorcycle-Bajaj CC 100

loans.name: Mari Cruz

texts.es:
Mari Cruz is married and has four children of her own. In addition, she cares for four younger siblings as if they were her own children, providing them with food, clothing and schooling. Since she was marrried she has enjoyed running her own business preparing typical regional dishes and has become well-known for her cooking, especially among the staff of organizations working in the area. She is cheerful and attentive with her customers. She hopes to use this loan to buy kitchen implements and set up a tortilla shop. The community needs a tortilla shop and to set it up means a large investment in equipment, firewood and corn. Mari Cruz is just the person to do it, as she is very well organized and responsible.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Doña Mari Cruz es casada tiene cuatro hijos legítimos y cuatro hermanos que son como sus hijos, porque desde pequeños se responsabilizo por cuidarlos y darles lo necesario, vestuario, alimentación y educación. Desde que se caso le ha gustado el comercio y su especialidad es preparar el plato típico de su región. Desde hace cinco años, se ha capacitado en la preparación de otros platillos de comida de las regiones cercanas a su comunidad, la mayoría de su clientela es personal de organizaciones que realizan eventos en el municipio, se ha identificado y su negocio ha sido reconocido por la especialidad de sus platillos, ha logrado éxito por su amabilidad y buena atención a su clientela. En su plan de inversión ha contemplado comprar utencilios de cocina que es lo que necesita y colocar una tortillería que es la demanda que se le ha presentado y la necesidad de su sector, debe comprar leña, maíz y la instalación de la cocina para preparar las tortillas, lo que significa una inversión grande, Ella es muy organizada y responsable.

loans.use: To buy kitchen implements and start a tortilla shop.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FAPE - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.en: Mrs. B. Adjovi is a married woman with 4 children. She started her business some years ago, but struggled to get an enough capital  to improve her business. She is applying for a loan of $100 so that she can buy more fish to resell. By doing so, she  will be able to make more profit and use it for her family's needs, and pay back this loan within 8 months. Thank you for your support.

loans.use: To buy fish, smoke them, and resell them.

loans.name: Afiwa

texts.en: Mrs. A. Afiwa is a married woman with three children.  She has been selling food for years to children at school, but with little profit. She is requesting  a loan of $400 so she can buy more food, resell it, and hopefully make more profit to then pay back her loan within 12 months. She will also use the profit to take care of her family's needs. Thank you for your support of her business. She is also a member of a group called Djidjole Group, sponsored by HELP Africa.

loans.use: To buy food and resell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for HELP Africa - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy goods and resell in pieces

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for HELP Africa - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
Maria Elena is married and the mother of three girls and a baby. She began in business selling fruit at the door of her house and she now keeps a general store with the help of her husband. She is very entrepreneurial so when she saw the opportunity she began taking bulk orders for her customers and this has helped the business grow. The shop has allowed her to help her husband support the family and give the girls an education and a better standard of living. The girls help their mother tend the shop, but Maria Elena's hope is to see them become successful professionals. She is very responsible and proud to offer good service. She will use this loan to buy soda to distribute to rural shops in her area.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Doña Maria Elena es casada, es madre de tres hijas y un bebe. Su esposo colabora en la atención de su negocio, inicio vendiendo frutas en la puerta de su casa, luego venta de productos de primera necesidad, ha sido una persona emprendedora, su negocio ha crecido y se ha convertido en una distribuidora a solicitud de su clientela que necesitaban productos por mayor cantidad, lo que ha hecho ahora surtir su negocio. Con el negocio que tiene ha logrado apoyar a su esposo en la educación de sus hijas, y darles una mejor vida también, ha sido de ayuda a otros negocios pequeños en surtirles productos. Ella espera que sus hijas sean profesionales y le ayuden a llevar el control de sus ventas. El préstamo lo invertirá en compra de aguas gaseosas para distribuirlas en los negocios que tiene en área rural cercana a su tienda y esta en un sector accesible para atenderlos, se ha caracterizado por su responsabilidad y esmero en la atención a sus clientes.

loans.use: To stock a general store and branch out into soft drink distribution.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy grain to resell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for HELP Africa - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria sells ice cream products during the day throughout the streets of Ayacucho and has been doing this for 19 years. She also sells sweets on a three wheeled cart at night; both these businesses she does as a traveling saleswoman. She also takes advantage of the Christmas season and sells panetones, traditional sweet holiday breads. She’s been a member of the Banco Comunal Yachay Wasi, which means House of Knowledge in Quechua, for 6 months. She enjoys the unity of the members, at the Banco she learned to be punctual, responsible, and how to educate her children. She says she is saving for when she is old and her health is declining. Maria needs a loan of 1000 soles ($350) to buy ice cream products and panetones for the holiday season and for the coming summer. In the future she would like to continue having good health and growing her business.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva Volunteer.

Maria vende helados durante el día por las calles de Ayacucho y esta actividad lo realiza hace 19 años. También vende dulces en un triciclo por la noche y ambos negocios en forma ambulatoria. Además en época se Navidad aprovecha y vende panetones. Ella está 6 meses en el banco Comunal Yachay Wasi que significa Casa del Saber en Quechua, le gusta la unión de las socias, en el Banco Comunal aprende a ser puntual, responsable y a como educar a los hijos. Ella dice que está ahorrando para cuando este viejita y se enferme. Maria necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles para invertir en la compra de helados y panetones para esta campaña navideña y el verano que se aproxima. En el futuro quisiera tener buena salud y hacer crecer su negocio.

loans.use: Maria needs a loan of 1000 Soles ($350) to buy ice cream products and panetones, traditional sweet holiday breads, for the holiday season and upcoming summer.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Food business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for HELP Africa - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ada Laura

texts.es:
Mrs. Ada Laura belongs to the communal bank, "Las Fresitas" (the small strawberries). She lives in Av. Colonizacion in the Yarina district, in the Ucayali department. She is 57 years old and mother of 4 children Her children are all grown up and have not to forgotten the sacrifice her mother has maD. for them, for which they are eternally grateful and very proud of their mother. Ada Laura is married and her husband works with her, but their income is not enough to cover the household expenses. With the first loan received from Manuela Ramos for S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) she was able to set up a stand to sell sodas, mineral water, beer, and at night she sells meals.

Right now she continues with this business. She and her husband get up at 6a.m. to open the store to give service to their customers. In the afternoons she prepares the food she will send at night.

With the recent loan received from Manuela Ramos for S/. 3,000 (US$ 1003.00 approx.) which will be paid in 6 months, she will stock her store with 6 packages of large sodas, 4 packages of mineral water, 5 boxes of small sodas, and maintain her store (for this she will use S/. 600.00), and with the rest she will buy the materials and supplies necessary for the daily sale of food.

Ada Laura feels very happy because her business is growing, she has more customers, and is very thankful for the support offered to her by Manuela Ramos. Thanks to this she has been able to achieve the family stability she hoped for so much.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Ada Laura pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Fresitas”, vive en la Av. Colonización, del distrito D. Yarina del departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 57 años y es madre D. 4 hijos, todos son mayores D. edad y no olvidan el sacrificio que su madre hizo por ellos, están eternamente agradecidos y muy orgullosos D. su madre. Ada Laura está casada, su esposo trabaja con ella, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos D. la casa. Con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300.00(US$ 100.00) pudo instalar una tienda D. venta D. gaseosas, agua mineral, cerveza, y por las noches se dedica a la venta D. comidas.

En la actualidad, continúa con este negocio. Ella y su esposo se levantan a las 6.00 D. la mañana para abrir la tienda y atender a sus clientes. Por las tardes prepara la comida que va a vender en la noche.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 3,000 (US$ 1003.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 6 meses, implementará su tienda con 6 paquetes D. gaseosa grandes, 4 paquetes D. agua mineral, 5 cajas D. gaseosas chicas, y dará mantenimiento a su tienda (para esto utilizará S/. 600.00), y con el resto comprará insumos y víveres que necesita para la venta diaria D. comida.

Ada Laura se siente muy feliz porque su negocio esta creciendo, tiene mas clientes y esta muy agradecida del apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos, gracias a ello ha encontrado una estabilidad familiar que tanto anhelaba.

loans.use: Buying sodas, mineral water, supplies and ingredients. (Compra de bebidas gaseosas, agua mineral.  Compra de insumos e ingredientes.)

loans.name: Mirna Ivon

texts.es:
Doña Mirna B. is 50 years old, single, and has 5 children, 3 of whom are adults and two who are children studying in grade school. She is ethnically Creole, originally from Bluefields. For the past 20 years she has been working baking coconut bread, sweet bread, lemon cake, soda cake, and coconut cake. She does her baking 4 times a week and has a demand for cakes for Christmas as well as weekly orders from her neighbors. This is why Mrs. B. needs financing to buy the materials to be able to make her bakery products. This micro-entrepreneur needs to buy 1 oil drum which costs US$27.00, 4 quintales (100 kg. sacks) of flour which cost US$32.00 each, 4 sacks of coal which she buys for US$ 10.00 per sack, 1quintal of salt which she buys for US $13.00, 4 boxes of eggs which she buys for US$ 13.00 per box, 20 lbs. of butter which she buys for $0.50 per pound, and 20 lbs. of lard, which she buys for US$ 0.80 per pound.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Mirna B. tiene 50 años de edad, es soltera, tiene 5 hijos 3 adultos y 2 niños, los cuales se encuentran estudiando en primaria, es de la etnia creole y originaria de Bluefields. Se dedica desde hace 20 años a hornar pan de coco, pan dulce, pastel de limon, soda queque y pastel de coco. Hace sus hornados 4 veces a la semana y tiene una demanda de pedidos de queques para navidad asi como los pedidos que semanalmente le hacen susu vecinos. Por tal razon es que doña B. necesita que le financien para comprar los insumos para poder hacer sus productos del horno. Esta microempresaria necesita comprar 1 bidon de aceite que le cuesta US$ 27.00 dolares, 4 quintales de harina que le cuestan US$ 32.00 dolares cada quintal, 4 sacos de carbon que los compra a US$ 10.00 dolares cada saco, 1 quintal de sal que compra a US$ 13.00 dolares, 4 cajillas de huevo que la compra a US$13.00 dolares cada cajilla, 20 libras de mantequilla que la compra a US$ 0.50 dolares cada libra y 20 libras de manteca la cual compra a US$ 0.80 cada libra.

loans.use: To buy a can of oil, 400 kg. of flour, 4 sacks of coal, 100kg. of salt, 4 boxes of eggs, 20 lbs. of butter, and 20 lbs. of lard. (Para comprar 1 bidon de aceite, 4 quintales de harina, 4 sacos de carbon 1 quintal de sal, 4 cajillas de huevo, 20 libras de mantequilla y 20 libras de manteca.)

payments.comment: La cuota real es de $23.83 dólares.
La cuota real es de US$ 23.83 dolares americanos.
La cuota real de pago es de $23.83 dólares americanos.
La cuota real de pago es de $ 23.83 dólares.
La cuota real de pago es de $ 23.83 dólares

loans.name: Las Gaviotas Group

texts.es:
The Seagulls Communal Bank started 2 years ago and has 23 members. Most of the members joined Finca through invitations from family and friends. They’re a united and happy group that loves to celebrate birthdays and they say that they’re like sisters.

The members need different amounts of money but the grand total to the Communal Bank would be $3825.00.

The members have different businesses such as selling fruits, prepared food, candies, CDs, clothes, and seasonal items depending on the festivals and times of year. Other businesses incluD. the production of traditional breads for the area, and emoliente which a local hot medicinal beverage that contains linseed and natural herbs that is sold at night and in the morning.

Each member has a story to tell, such as Lucia who sells clothes. Her biggest wish was to buy land and she was able to accomplish this thanks to the money she saved in the Communal Bank; now she has other dreams.

They will use the loan to buy rice, oil, noodles, papers, cookies, sugar, gums, cigars; those that make bread will buy basic necessities such as flour, yeast, and wood; and those that produce the herbal emoliente, linseed and herbs.

The main dreams of the members is to see their businesses prosper, they want day by day to have a bigger store, a commercial store, or a mechanic shop.

At Finca they learned to be punctual and always save.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Hernandez, Kiva Volunteer.

El Banco Comunal Las Gaviotas se inició hace 2 años y actualmente tiene 7 ciclos y 23 socias. Muchas D. las socias llegaron a Finca a través D. L. invitación D. familiares y amigos. Es un grupo unido y alegre que les gusta festejar cumpleaños, ellas mencionan que son como hermanas.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 200 soles, 400 soles, 600 soles haciendo un total D. 11400 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como L. venta D. frutas, comida, golosinas, CDs, ropa, artículos D. novedad por campaña esto depenD. D. las fiestas y fechas. Otros negocios son L. elaboración D. panes tradicionales D. L. zona, emoliente que es una bebida caliente y medicinal que contiene linaza y hierbas D. L. zona que se venD. en las noches y mañanas.

Cada socia tiene una historia que contar, como el caso D. Lucia que venD. ropa y su mayor sueño fue comprar un terreno y lo logró gracias a lo que ahorró en su Banco Comunal y ahora tiene otros sueños.

Los préstamos lo invertirán en L. compra D. arroz, aceite, fideo, papeles, galletas, azúcar, chicles, cigarros, y los que elaboran pan para L. compra D. insumos como L. harina, levadura, leña y los que elaboran emoliente hierbas, linaza que es una semilL. proveniente D. L. planta D. lino y las hierbas.

Los sueños D. las socias principalmente es que su negocio prospere, otros mencionan que poco a poco puedan tener una tienda granD., una tienda comercial, tener un taller.

En Finca aprendieron a ser puntuales y ahorrar siempre.

loans.use: The loans will be used to buy rice, oil, noodles, papers, cookies, sugar, gum, cigars; those that make bread will buy basic necessities such as flour, yeast, and wood; and those that produce the herbal emoliente, linseed and herbs.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
Elizabeth belongs to the Communal Bank Las Activas, she lives in Asentamiento Humano Señor D. los Milagros Jr. Pachacutec Mz A1 Lt. 06, Calleria district, Ucayali state. She is 52 years old and mother of 7 children, her husband is a motocycle-taxi driver, but the income doesn't meet the household expenses. So Elizabeth, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos for 300 Soles (US$100.00), decided to put a small chicken retail stand in the Bellavista market.

Because of her business she gets up at 1 AM to go and purchase the chickens in order to be able to sell them starting at 5 AM. Sales normally finish at 1 PM, then she goes home to rest and prepare to do it all again the next day.

With the recent loan from Manuela Ramos for 1000 Soles (approximately US$334), which will be repaid in 5 months, she will increase her usual purchase, now she will buy 70 chickens daily, and thereby increase her income.

Elizabeth is very happy to see her business prosper, as that is an important achievement for her, and thanks to this success she has helped her family's well-being.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Elizabeth pertenece al Banco Comunal las Activas, vive en el Asentamiento Humano Señor D. los Milagros Jr. Pachacutec Mz A1 Lt. 06, del distrito Calleria, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 52 años D. edad y es madre D. 7 hijos, su esposo es motocarrista, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos del hogar, es así que Elizabeth, con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300.00 (US$100.00) deciD. poner una pequeña tienda D. venta D. pollos en el mercado Bellavista.

Debido a su negocio, se levanta a la 1 D. la mañana para ir a comprar las javas D. pollo y así poder iniciar la venta D. los mismos a partir D. las 5 a.m. La venta, normalmente termina a la 1 p.m., luego se dirige a su domicilio para descansar y prepararse para la rutina del día siguiente.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 1,000 (US$ 334.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 5 meses, incrementará la compra habitual D. pollos, ahora comprará 70 pollos a diario, D. esta manera incrementará sus ingresos.

Elizabeth está muy contenta D. ver que su negocio prospera, ya que es un logro muy importante para ella, gracias a éste ha alcanzado el bienestar D. su familia.

loans.use: Purchase butchered chickens

loans.name: Justina

texts.es:
Mrs. Justina belongs to the communal bank, "Teresa Ramos", she lives in Jr. Aguaita No. 559, Yarina Concha district, Ucayali department. She is 40 years old and mother of 5 children who are minors. She is married and her husband is a fisherman, but his income is not enough for the family expenses, so Justina decided to start a business with her first loan received from Manuela Ramos for S/300.00 (US$100.00), selling fish.

Right now she has a small space inside the market of Yarinacoha for selling fish. They wake up at 4am to feed their children and then get ready to go to the market to sell her product.

With the recent loan from Manuela Ramos for S/.1,000 (US $334.00 approximately), which will be paid in 4 months, she will buy more fish (approx. 10 kilos boquichico, 15 kilos bagre, 30 kilos palometa, 20 kilos llambina, etc.) as well as 40 blocks of ice, 40 gallons of gas for their boat and S/.60.00 for supplies.

Justina is very happy because the sales of her fish increase every day, as well as her clientele whom she attends to with much love, enthusiasm, and dedication. With the sales of her fish she will be able to support her younger children in their studies because they need her total support so will time they will be able to go to college, which is Justina's biggest dream... seeing her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Justina pertenece al Banco Comunal “Teresa Ramos”, vive en Jr. Aguaita No 559, del distrito de Yarina Cocha del departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 40 años y es madre de 5 hijos que son menores de edad, está casada, su esposo es armador de pesca, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos familiares, es así que Justina, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decide poner un negocio de venta de pescado.

En la actualidad cuenta con un pequeño espacio dentro del mercado de yarinacoha para la venta de pescado. Se levantan a las 4.00 de la mañana para darles de comer a sus hijos, y luego se prepara para dirigirse al mercado para la venta de su producto.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,000 (US$ 334.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará mas pescado (aprox. 10 kilos boquichico, 15 kilos bagre, 30 kilos de palometa, 20kilos de llambina, etc.), así también comprará 40 barras de hielo, 40 galones de gasolina para su bote y S/. 60.00 invertirá en víveres.

Justina está muy contenta, porque la venta de sus pescados cada día aumenta mas, así como su clientela a la cual atiende con mucho cariño y le pone mucho esfuerzo y dedicación, con la venta de sus pescados puede apoyar en los estudios a sus menores hijos que necesitan de su total apoyo. Y con el tiempo ellos puedan seguir una carrera universitaria, que es el sueño más grande de Justina..... ver profesionales a sus hijos.

loans.use: Buying fish wholesale. Buying blocks of ice and gas for transportation. (Compra de pescados al por mayor.  Compra de barras de hielo y gasolina para transporte.)

loans.name: Dinora

texts.es:
Dinora G. is 33-years-old, is a native of the city of Bluefields, and is married to Ramón Rosales. They have 7 children. Mrs. G. is the owner of a business in which she sells cheese and cream. She has 2 years of experience. Her clients are men and women of all ages who prefer her because she offers a delivery service. Mrs. G. needs to buy 253 pounds of cheese at $1 each and 16 pounds of cream at $0.82 per pound. This investment will let her cover her demand.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La Sra Dinora G. tiene 33 años de edad, es originaria de la ciudad de Bluefields, esta casada con el Sr. Ramón Rosales ambos tiene 7 hijos. La Sra G. es propietaria de un tramo donde vende queso y crema, tiene 2 años de experiencia. Sus clientes son hombre y mujeres de todas las edades que la prefieren por brindar un servicio a domicilio. La Sra G. necesita comprar 253 libras de queso a C$1.00 dólar cada libra y 16 libras de crema a C$ 0.82 centavos dólar la libra, con esta inversión podrá cubrir su demanda.

loans.use: To purchase cheese and cream

payments.comment: La cuota real que pago es de $ 22.17 dólares.
La cuota real de pago es de $ 22.17 dólares
La cuota eral es de US$ 22.17 dolares.
La cuota real es de $ 22.17 dólares

loans.name: Paula

texts.es:
Paula L. is a woman who, in spite of all the trials that life has given her, has been able to succeed. Ten years ago she separated from her husband, "In those days I worked washing and ironing other people's clothes, but I suffered an accident that left me immobilized in the arms, " Paula commented. However, this problem did not make her fall since she had to move forward for her hour children, so that they wouldn't suffer for the loss of a father figure and did not stop studying. This is why Paula started looking for a way to make money in a way that did not require her to move her arms so much. And so it was that she started selling used clothes among her neighbors, family, and friends. Little by little she acquired more customers who would ask her for new things, and so it was that she started buying new clothes and shoes to be able to have variety to offer to her customers.

Right now, her youngest daughter who is 25, is the only one living with her, and on some occasions she helps out in the store since she has a humble job. Her other children are married and have other expenses so they cannot help Paula with her expenses. This is why Paula keeps working hard so that her business can succeed and so she doesn't have to depend totally on her children. Paula is requesting a loan for US $375 to be paid in a period of 4 months. With this money Paula will be able to buy more merchandise for the end of the year in which a lot of people like wearing new clothes to celebrate With your help, Paula will be able to grow her business and succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Paula L. es una mujer que a pesar de todos los retos que la vida le a puesto a sabido superarlos. Hace diez años se separó de su esposo “En ese tiempo yo me dedicaba a lavar y a planchar ropa ajena pero sufrí un accidente que me dejo inmovilidad en los brazos” comentó Paula. Sin embargo este problema no la dejó caer puesto que tenía que salir adelante por sus cuatros hijos para que ellos no resintieran la pérdida de una figura paterna y que no dejaran de estudiar. Fue así como Paula comenzó a buscar una manera de obtener dinero pero que no requiriera mover tanto los brazos. Y fue así como comenzó a vender ropa usada entre sus vecinos, familiares y amigos. Y poco a poco fue adquiriendo más clientes que cada vez le iban pidiendo cosas nuevas, y fue así que comenzó a comprar ropa nueva y calzado para poder tener variedad qué ofrecerle a sus clientes.

Actualmente la hija más chica, de 25 años es la única que vive con ella y en ocasiones la ayuda en la tienda, puesto que ella ya tiene un trabajo modesto. Y sus otros hijos ya están casado y tienen otros gastos por eso no pueden ayudarla con todos los gastos que ella tiene. Es por eso que Paula continua trabajando y luchando por que su negocio salga adelante, y así no tener que depender totalmente de sus hijos. Paula está solicitando un crédito de US $375 para pagarlos en un plazo de 4 meses y con este dinero Paula podrá comprar más mercancía para la este fin de año que muchas personas les gusta estrenar en esta celebración. Con tu ayuda Paula podrá crecer su negocio y salir adelante.

loans.use: Buying new merchandise to stock her business (Comprar mercancía nueva para surtir su negocio)

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia A. began using natural products in order to have a better quality of life for herself and her husband, who is a tractor trailer driver and this work tires his back and kidneys a lot because of the extended time seated. Little by little she realized that she was using more and more of these products so she decided to become a distributor of this type of products in order to have the possibility of getting extra income in addition to her husband's income.

Nevertheless the Christmas season is a very good time to sell this type of product because it is when her customers have more money to be able to sell them natural products, and for this reason Julia is asking for a US$375 loan to be repaid in 4 months. With this money Julia will be able to buy more merchandise to have something to offer her customers. With your help Julia will be able to succeed, just like her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

Julia A. comenzó por consumir productos naturistas para tener una mejor calidad de vida a ella y a su esposo quien es chofer de traileres y este trabajo le cansa mucho la espalda al igual que los riñones al permanecer mucho tiempo sentado. Poco a poco se dio cuenta que estaba consumiendo más y más así que decidió comenzar a ser distribuiora de este tipo de productos para poder tener la posibilidad de obtener ingresos extras a lo que gana su esposo como trailero.

Sin embargo la temporada de navidad es muy buena para ofrecer este tipo de productos puesto que es cuando sus clientes tienen más dinero para poder venderles productos naturistas, es por eso que Julia está solicitando un crédito de US $375 para poder pagarlos en un plazo de 4 meses y con este dinero Julia podrá comprar más mercancía para tener algo que ofrecerles a sus clientes. Con tu ayuda Julia podrá salir adelante igual que su esposo.

loans.use: Purchase more natural products and merchandise.

loans.name: Irma Yolanda

texts.es:
Irma Yolanda is a 61 year old woman with a lot of enthusiasm for life and staying productive for society. She has three children who are already all married and who live outside of her home. Irma lives only with her husband who is already retired and living off the retirement pension he got. However, this money is not enough to pay the their household expenses. This is why Irma has been working selling jewelry through catalogue to neighbors and friends. Since she was much younger, Irma has been selling different kinds of things, from homemade meals, to clothes, to beauty products among other things, but right now she sells jewelry.

However, in this Christmas season Irma is requesting a loan for US $375 to be paid in a period of 4 months, and with this money Irma will be able to buy merchandise such as rings, bracelets, necklaces, earrings, pendants, etc, to be able to have products to offer to her customers. With your help Irma will be able to do well and help her husband with the household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Irma Yolanda una mujer de 61 con muchas ganas de vivir, y seguir siendo productiva para la sociedad. Tiene 3 hijos los cuales ya están casados todos y viven fuera de su casa. Irma vive solamente con su esposo quien ya está jubilado y vive sólo de la pensión que le dieron. Sin embargo con este dinero no les alcanza para pagar los gastos de su casa. Es por eso que Irma se dedica a vender joyería por catálogo a sus vecinas y amigos. Desde que era más joven doña Irma se dedicó a vender varios tipos de cosas desde elaborar comidas, vender ropa, productos de belleza entre otras cosas pero hoy se dedica a vender joyería.

Sin embargo en esta temporada navideña Irma está solicitando un crédito de US $375 para pagarlos en un plazo de 4 meses y con este dinero Irma podrá comprar mercancía tales como anillos, pulseras, cadenas, arracadas, aretes, dijes, etc. Para poder tener productos que ofrecerle a sus clientes. Con tu ayuda Irma podrá salir adelante y ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos del hogar.

loans.use: Buying jewelry to offer to her customers (Comprar joyería para ofrecerle a sus clientes)

loans.name: Susana Gabriela

texts.es:
Susana divorced recently and is going through a sad stage in her life. However, she has two children for whom she needs to move forward and work hard so that they may have a better future than she did. Two years before getting divorced, Susana started a small business selling tacos and menudos (tripe soup), and little by little, with a lot of effort, she got customers who came to buy menudos. However, her business has started to decrease, and she doesn't want it to close for lack of attention.

This is why Susana is requesting a loan for US$1125 to be paid in a period of 6 months. With this money Susana will be able to adapt her locale so that it draw the attention of potential customers and so little by little she can grow her small locale. With your help, Susana and her children will be able to have a nice Christmas, and will be able to make it through this trying time life has thrown at them.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Susana acaba D. divorciarse y pasa por una etapa triste D. su vida. Sin embargo tiene dos hijos por quienes salir adelante y luchar para que ellos tengan un mejor futuro que elL.. Hace dos años antes D. divorciarse, Susana comenzó con un pequeño negocio D. ventas D. tacos y menudos, y poco a poco y con mucho esfuerzo fue haciéndose D. clientes que le iban a comprar menudos. Sin embargo a raíz D. su negocio comenzó a decaer y elL. no quiere que este negocio se cierre por falta D. atención.

Es por es oque Susana está solicitando un crédito D. US $1125 para pagarlos en un plazo D. 6 meses y con este dinero Susana podrá acondicionar su local, para que llame L. atención a más clientes Y así pueda crecer poco a poco su pequeño local. Con tu ayuda Susana y sus hijos podrán tener una bonita navidad, y podrán salir delante D. esta prueba que L. vida les dio.

loans.use: Recomedling her small food locale (Remodelar su pequeño local de comida)

loans.name: Verónica

texts.es:
Veronica B. is a young woman who is studying. However, her parents do not have enough income to cover her schooling expenses. This is why Veronica decided to start her own business of selling shoes through catalogues and this way she does not need to have a fixed scheduled, since she offers them to her own schoolmates and neighbors. Two years ago she started selling shoes and little by little she has gathered customers who seek her to buy shoes since she sells them on credit to offer her customers the opportunity to pay her back though a longer period of time.

However, because of the Christmas season, the demand for shoes has increased This is why Veronica is requesting a loan for US$475 to be paid in a period of 6 months. With this money, Veronica will be able to buy more merchandise to have a larger variety and offer her customers what they are looking for. With your help Veronica will be able to continue with her business and with the income obtained during this season she will be able to save to pay the registration fees for the next school year.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Verónica B. es una chica que está estudiando, sin embargo sus padres no cuentan con muchos ingresos como para seguir costeando los gastos que le representa la escuela. Es por esto que Verónica decidió emprender su propio negocio al vender zapatos por catálogo y así no necesita tener un horario fijo, puesto que estos los ofrece entre sus compañeros de la escuela y sus vecinos.
