Hace 2 años comenzó a vender zapatos y poco a poco se ha ido haciendo de clientes que la buscan para poder pedirles zapatos puesto que ella los vende en plazo para que sus clientes tengan la facilidad de pagarle en más tiempo.

Sin embargo por la temporada navideña, la demanda de los zapatos incrementa, y es por esto que Verónica está solicitando un crédito de US $475 para pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Verónica podrá comprar más mercancía para tener mayor variedad y ofrecerles a sus clientes lo que ellos andan buscando. Con tu ayuda Verónica podrá seguir con su negocio y con las ganancias que obtenga en esta temporada podrá ahorrar para poder pagar la inscripción de su siguiente grado en la escuela.

loans.use: Buying merchandise to sell in the winter (Comprar mercancía para vender en invierno)

loans.name: Teresa De Jesús

texts.es:
Teresa de Jesus is a woman who studied to be an accountant. For a long time she worked as an accountant in a auto parts store. However, in a personnel "readjustment" she was fired. This left Teresa without that income that she received in her home. That is how she started looking for work, but she did not succeed and the household expenses grew more and more. Therefore, she decided to start her own business to be able to obtain extra income because what her husband makes as a chauffeur was not enough. In the beginning, Teresa sold general store merchandise, but later her customers started asking for haberdashery items as well as office supplies. This is why her business includes these three types of products right now.

Little by little Teresa increased her customers and right now she is in a good position in her neighborhood. However, Teresa thinks this is a good moment to increase her business, to stock merchandise for the Christmas season. This is why she is requesting a loan for US $ 575 to be paid in a period of 6 months. With this money Teresa will be able to paint her locale and buy merchandise like wrapping paper and house decorations. With your help, Teresa will be able to make her business succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Teresa de Jesús es una mujer que estudió para ser contadora. Durante mucho tiempo se dedicó a ser contadora en una refraccionaria. Sin embargo en un reajuste de personal la despidieron. Quedando Teresa desprotegida de ese ingreso extra que recibía en su casa. Así fue que comenzó a buscar trabajo, sin embargo no tenía éxito y los gastos en el hogar se hacían cada vez más grandes, por lo tanto decidió comenzar su propio negocio para poder obtener ingresos extras. Puesto que con lo que gana su esposo como chofer no les alcanzaba. En un inicio Teresa vendía mercancía de abarrotes. Pero después sus clientes comenzaron a pedirle cosas de mercería y de papelería. Es por eso que actualmente tiene un negocio en donde mezcla estos tres tipos de productos.

Poco a poco Teresa se fue haciendo de clientes y actualmente ya se encuentra más posicionada dentro de su colonia. Sin embargo Teresa considera que es momento para crecer su negocio y para surtir de mercancía para la temporada navideña. Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito de US $575 Para pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Teresa podrá pintar su local y comprar mercancía para envolver regalos y adornos para las casas. Con tu ayuda Teresa podrá sacar adelante su negocio.

loans.use: Painting her locale and buying merchandise for the Christmas season. (Pintar su local y comprar mercancía para la temporada navideña)

loans.name: Eva

texts.es:
Eva started a general store business 5 years ago because they couldn't cover the expenses for their four children, because her husband works as a bus driver. Eva started adapting the entrance to her house with a metal sheet roof, and little by little it has been growing and she has gotten more customers and making her little store better. Currently, she has been able to build a concrete roof so thieves cannot come in because before that the roof could be easily bent or broken because of how old and rusted the metal sheet was.

However, Eva does not have a lot of merchandise right now, and this is why she is requesting a loan for US$650 to be paid in a period of 6 months. With this money Eva will be able to buy more merchandise for the Christmas season, materials to make tamales, Christmas dinner, and things for the posadas (pre-Christmas celebrations). "Knowing how to invest this money will be very useful to me because right now it is a season of good income since it is when people have money," Eva commented. With your help, Eva will be able to move her business forward.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Hace 5 años que Eva comenzó con un negocio de abarrotes, puesto que no le alcanzaba para pagar los gastos de sus cuatro hijos, puesto que su esposo trabaja como chofer de línea de autobuses. Eva comenzó adecuando la entrada de su casa con un techo de lámina y poco a poco creciendo ha ido haciéndose de clientes y adecuando mejor su pequeña tienda. Actualmente ya pudo hacer un techo de concreto para que los ladrones no puedan entrar. Puesto que antes era muy fácil doblar y o romper la lámina por lo viejita y oxidada que estaba.

Sin embargo actualmente Eva no tiene mucha mercancía, por lo tanto está solicitando un crédito de US $650 para pagarlos en un plazo de 6 meses y con este dinero Eva podrá comprar más mercancía para la temporada navideña, materiales para elaborar los tamales, la cena navideña, y cosas para las posadas. “Sabiendo invertir este dinero me servirá de mucho porque ahorita es temporada de buenas ganancias porque la gente es cuando trae dinero” Comentó Eva. Con tu ayuda Eva podrá sacar adelante su negocio.

loans.use: Buying merchandise for her customers' Christmas dinners. (Comprar mercancía para las cenas navideñas que realizan sus clientes)

loans.name: Nani

texts.en: Nani D. is 34 years old and has a 10-year-old child. She sells household goods such as cooking oil, rice, eggs, and kerosene in her small shop. Her husband, Odih, has no regular income. She usually earns $7 per day. She is requesting a loan of $75 so she can improve her stock and earn more income. Nani is a member of MBK and is will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods to fill her shop

loans.name: Eneng

texts.en: Eneng U. is 30 years old and a mother of child aged 10. She has been running her business by sells clothes on credit. She also sells electronic goods such as television, radio etc. She usually earns profit US$10 per month. Her husband, Sahuri, has running her business by collect and sells waste and scrap materials. He can earns US$2 per day. She really needs IDR 900,000 loan to expand her and her husband business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Expansion business

loans.name: Junah

texts.en: Junah is 24 years old and a mother of a child, aged 10. She collects and sells waste and scrap materials. Sometimes she also sells spare parts if someone need it. She can earns US $5 per day and it is just enough to cover their day-to-day necessities. Her husband, A., is a driver, who earns US $2 per day. She needs a loan to expand her business and make it more sustainable to support their family needs. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Nyai

texts.en: Nyai is 32 years old and a mother of a child, aged 15. Together with her husband Wawan, she has been running her business by collecting and selling waste and scrap materials. They also sell spare parts and usually earn US $20 per day. She needs a loan to expand her business by completing her inventory, so that she can sell more goods and earn more income. She is a member of MBK and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Een

texts.en: Een is 48 years old and has a 14-year-old child. She is a tailor who also provides a tailoring course at her home. She earns $2 per day, but in festive season she often earns more. Her husband, Eroni, is an employee in Jakarta who earns $50 per month. They both work very hard for their child's education. Een requests a loan of $100 to buy clothes and dressmaking supplies which will improve her business and her income. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy clothes and dressmaking supplies

loans.name: Evon

texts.en: Evon is 18 years old and is married with a one year old child. She has been selling some spare parts together with her husband, U., who is also a driver . She usually earns US$10 per day. She needs a loan to expand her business and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Elis

texts.en: Elis is 33 years old and has a 14 year old child. She has  been selling food at her small stall and also selling cosmetics on credit. She previously closed down her business due to  being short of capital. Now she is starting her business again and could earn US$5 per day. She really needs a loan to buy more goods and hopes that she can earn more income to support her family needs. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Basty

texts.en: 26 year old Basty (her husband is pictured) is married and has one child. She lives in the Khudat town. She has two years of experience in  the dairy business. She needs a loan of $850 to purchase a cow and increase the the size of her milking herd and her milk production.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Kamil

texts.en: 49 year old Kamil  lives in Khachmaz town with his wife and 3 children. He has a butcher shop. This man buys calves to process and sell for meat.  He needs a loan of $950 to buy 2 calves.

loans.use: To buy 2 calves

loans.name: Carolina Jorge

texts.pt:
Carolina lives in the village of Samora Machel, district of Manjacaze. She is a single mother of 1 son. Her mother and brothers moved in with her after her mother separated from her husband and they currenlty live with her. Carolina joined the program this year. She also works at the village's rural hospital as a janitor. Because her salary is so low, her business helps her supplement her income and support her family. Her mother helps her out by keeping up their small house. Carolina's son and brother are in school. In the future, if her business grows strong, she dreams of building a home made of durable materials for her and her family.

Translated by Camila, Kiva volunteer.

Carolina vive na aldeia Samora Machel no distrito de Manjacaze. Ela e mae solteira e tem 1 filho. Para alem do filho ela vive com a mae e seus irmaos. Isto porque a mae separou-se do marido e veio viver para casa de Carolina. Carolina entrou para o programa de credito ainda este ano. Carolina e tambem trabalhadora do Hospital Rural da vila do mesmo nome como servente. Como servente o seu salario e baixo assim ela reforca o orcamento familiar com o negocio que ela faz. A mae de Carolina ajuda a filha nas despesas trabalhando na pequena machamba familiar. O filho e os irmaos de Carolina estao a estudar. No futuro Carolina diz que se o negocio correr bem e crescer ela sonha en construir uma residencia usando material convencional.

loans.use:
Carolina wants to use the money to buy more clothing for sale.

Carolina quer usar o dinheiro para acompra de mais fardos de roupa para a venda

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel F. G. is in the transport business. He owns two taxis. He works with one as a taxi driver. He is married with two children ages 11and 9. His wife is a seamstress, supporting the family in her little way. At the moment one of the taxis is not functioning.

He is asking for $1,200 to buy a new engine and also do other maintenance work to facilitate the smooth running of his car.

loans.use: Buy a new engine and also do other maintenance work

loans.name: Mathew

texts.en:
Mathew A. is a commercial driver; he has two taxis which he works with. He is married with four children ages 15, 13, 10 and 6. His wife is a trader who deals in food supplies. She is helping with the family finances. One of his taxis is parked at the garage because there is a problem with the engine. He also has to do some body work on the car.

He is asking for $1,200 to enable him buy a new engine and perform other maintenance work to put the vehicle back on the road.

loans.use: Buy a new engine and perform other maintenance work

loans.name: Helena Felipe

texts.pt:
Helena is married and lives with her husband at Praia do Bilene. She has 2 sons that are in elementary school. She was a part of a group that used this program and when the group dissolved she decided to continue to use the program as a individual client. Since she joined the loan program in 2005 she always sold commodity products, but now she would like to start selling attire as well. Her husband works with her in the sale of products. They began building a new residence made of more durable material than their previous house and their business is progressing well. Helena is crossing a difficult moment in her social life where her husband has been sick and she has had to take care of their business, children and husband all by herself, but she is confident that she is can do it.

Translated from Portuguese by Camila, Kiva volunteer.

Helena e casada e vive com o marido na praia do Bilene. Helena tem 2 filhos que estao a estudar no ensino primario basico. Ela entrou para o programa em 2005. Ela era membro de um grupo. Quandop o grupo se desfez ela preferiu continuar como cliente individual. desde que entrou para o programa em 2005 sempre vendeu produtos de primeira necessidade. Mas agora ela quer introduzir tambem a venda de roupa.O marido de Helena trabalha junto com ela na venda. Eles iniciaram a construccao de uma residencia nova feita com material convenciaonal. A antiga foi feita com material local. O negocio de Helena esta a correr bem. Helena esta a atravessar um momento dificilna sua vida social. O seu marido tem andado doente assim ela tem de se desdobrar para cuidar do negocio, dos filhos e do marido. Mas ela diz que consegue gerir tudo isso.

loans.use: Helena wants to use the money for the purchase of additional supplies and clothing for sale at her shop.

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah O. is a trader who deals in car spare parts. She is divorced with two children ages 15 and 3 in her custody. Raising two kids single-handedly is not easy for Hannah but she is trying. There is an increase in demand for car spare parts but she is not able to meet the demand. Her shop is located at a very good place near mechanical shops.

She is asking for $1,100 to enable her buy more spare parts for her shop. This loan will enable her meet the demand of her customers and also maximize her profit which will raise her living condition.

loans.use: Buy more spare parts for her shop

loans.name: Francis Atta

texts.en:
Francis Arthur G. is into repairing electrical appliances. He is a multi-purpose man who specializes in repairing generators, stabilizers, transformers, blenders, ceiling and standing fans, step-up and step-down, irons, kettles, corn mill motors and others machines. He is currently training two boys who will be helping him to reduce the work load. He is not married. He is lacking material to carry out his business.

He is asking for $1,200 to buy rewinding wires, fan parts, solution papers, electrical cables, sockets, plugs, etc. to enable him continue with his repair work.

loans.use: Buy rewinding wires, fan parts, solution papers, electrical cables, sockets, plugs, etc.

loans.name: Tamara Abilio

texts.pt:
Tamara is legally single but lives in a social marriage with a man with 2 sons. Tamara opened her shop in her residence, where she runs the business. She expanded beyond the sale of commodity products by selling fire wood. Her husband is a public transportation driver and makes little money, so Tamara decided to join the loan program to help with their living and household expenses. The children are still young, but they will grow and need to go to school, and the couple have made the necessary sacrifices to afford the children's basic needs. Since joining the program in 2006 her live has improved and they continue to build their residence in stages. Tamara wants to work hard to make sure that her business continues to grow profitably.

Translated by Camila, Kiva volunteer.

Tamara e solteira mas vive maritalmente com um homem com quem tem 2 filhos. Tamara abriu uma tenda na sua residencia onde faz o negocio. Introduziu para alem da venda de produtos de primeira necessidade a venda de lenha. Tudo isto e feito na sua residencia. O marido de Tamara e motorista de um transporte semicolectivo de passageiros vulgo chapa 100. Como condutor de chapas o seu salario e baixo por isso Tamara teve que entrar no programa para ajudar o marido nas despesas da casa. Os filhos de Tamara ainda sao pequenos. mas irao crescer e terao que estudar. Por isso ocasal tem de se sacrificar para que nada faltre aos filhos.Tamara entrou para o programa em 2006 .De la para ca a sua vida tem registado melhorias.O casal esta paulatinamente construindo a sua residencia e ela diz que vai trabalhar muito no sentido de a concluir com os rendimentos do negocio.

loans.use:
Tamara wants to use the money for the purchase of additional supplies and fire wood for sale at her shop.

Tamara quer usar o dinheiro para a compra de mais produtos para asua tendinha e comprar mais lenha para a venda

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John S. is a carpenter who specializeds in making furniture. He is not married and has no children. John is losing his costumers due to the fact that he is still using his old methods of manufacturing, which are slower. He wants to change with the times and go into the mechanical method.

He is asking for $1,200 to buy a cutting machine, tools, electrical sprayers and other equipment to enable him to stay in business.

loans.use: Buy a cutting machine, tools, electrical sprayers

loans.name: Ishrat

texts.en: I need a loan of $250 for my stitching business and my husband’s cloth dying business. With this loan I plan to buy an additional stitching machine and my husband will buy some stuff required for dying clothes. Both of us work very hard to uplift our family’s financial status. Eid( a muslim religious festival) is around the corner and we hope to generate higher profits by taking on bigger orders.

loans.use: Buy a stitching machine and stuff required for dying clothes

loans.name: Ishrat

texts.en: I need a loan of $250 for my stitching business and my husband’s cloth dying business. With this loan I plan to buy an additional stitching machine and my husband will buy some stuff required for dying clothes. Both of us work very hard to uplift our family’s financial status. Eid( a muslim religious festival) is around the corner and we hope to generate higher profits by taking on bigger orders.

loans.use: Buy a stitching machine and stuff required for dying clothes

loans.name: Ishrat

texts.en: I need a loan of $250 for my stitching business and my husband’s cloth dying business. With this loan I plan to buy an additional stitching machine and my husband will buy additional materials required for dying clothes. Both of us work very hard to uplift our family’s financial status. Eid, a muslim religious festival, is around the corner and we hope to generate higher profits by taking on bigger orders for the festival.

loans.use: Buy a stitching machine and materials required for dying clothes

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en: I am a widow. I have ten children, six boys and four girls. My eldest son is the only breadwinner for the family and he operates a cosmetics store. He wants to begin to sell jewelry at his store along with cosmetics. He wants to do so because his customers are requesting a good variety of jewelry at his store so that they do not have to travel to far off areas to purchase jewelry. I therefore request a loan of $350 for my son’s store. With this money he will buy the latest variety of jewelry for his store.

loans.use: Buy a range of jewelry for the current store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Bangkok Group

texts.en:
Abdugapur (second from left in the photo) leads this team of Microinvest clients, who call themselves the Bangkok Group. He was chosen as leader because he has been in the business of rearing and selling farm animals for 10 years. He is widely known in his community as an expert in this field, and people routinely come to him for help or advice about how to breed cattle.

The second member is Turgunoi (far left), who has been in the business of animal husbandry for more than three years. Currently, she is raising one cow with the help of her three children. Mamadjon (second from right) is raising three young calves, which he plans to sell when they are grown. Mavlonkul (far right), the fourth and last member of this group, is very experienced at raising sheep and hogs.

The Bangkok Group is one of the most honest and diligent clients we have at Microinvest. The members are very friendly and always willing to help each other repay their loan on time. Abdugapur will use his portion of the new loan to buy fodder. Turgunoi will buy two baby calves. Mamadjon and Mavlonkul will use their money to rebuild their farm.

loans.use: For business expansion.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her tailoring business.

loans.name: Fotima

texts.en: Fotima G. is married and has three children. She has been a Microinvest client since 2004, and in that time has used several loans to increase her sales volume and attract many new clients. She is a very skilled saleswoman, and people like to do business with her because she is polite, energetic and has a great selection of shoes to choose from. She buys these shoes in Istaravshan and Isfara and sells them in the community where she lives, Spitamen. Sales are strong, and she has applied for a loan to buy new inventory and further expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Ghazala

texts.en: I am Ghazala B.. I am married and a mother of three. My eldest daughter is in kindergarten, but my other two children are not of school age yet. My husband operates a fruits business in a nearby fruit market. I am a seamstress. I create dresses on order from various clients. My husband wants to expand his fruits business and to do this requires a loan of $200.

loans.use: Expand her husband's fruits business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Shahlo

texts.en: Shahlo U. is a young woman with 2 children. She is occupied with carpets’ business 7 years. She considers this type of business more profitable and that’s why she wants and wishes her business growth, to buy different types of carpets and make its assortment manifold. She applies to KIVA for the loan and hopes that with the help of this loan she will fulfill her purpose.

loans.use: Increasing goods' assortment

loans.name: Shahlo

texts.en: Shahlo U. is a young woman with two children who has been in the business of selling carpets for the last seven years. She went into this line of work because it has the potential to be very profitable, and because there is lots of opportunity for growth. Shahlo is committed to expand her business, and has come to us for a loan to increase the number and types of carpets she has for sale in her shop.

loans.use: Increasing the assortment of goods for sale

loans.name: Khursheed

texts.en:
I am Khursheed B.. I am married and a mother of seven, four boys and three girls. I live with my family in a big city, Lahore, Pakistan. I stay at home and do my household chores; I do not go out and work because I have grown old and my sons have started earning income. My husband owns a vegetable business in a nearby market.

One of my sons paints and polishes furniture on order. My son is in the process of expanding his business so that he can take on bigger orders and thus increase his income. He wants to give to us so that we can be comfortable and worry free in our old age. For this purpose he requires a loan for his business.

loans.use: Expand furniture business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Muqqadas

texts.en: I am Muqqadas B.. I am married and a mother of seven children, two boys and five girls. Three of my daughters are done with their studies while the other two are in grades five and one, respectively. My sons are small and they also attend school, so my husband is the only one supporting our family. My husband operates a small hotel in one of the nearby, more crowded areas. He wants to expand his business and requires a loan of $200 for this purpose. With this loan he will buy table chairs and a stock of flour for his business. This loan will help him to earn more for us and keep us comfortable.

loans.use: Buy furniture for the resturant

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mayram

texts.en: Mayram A. is the mother of four children and has been a Microinvest client since 2004. Over the last few years, she has used several loans to increase the size of her business and win many new clients. Because the unemployment rate is high in Tajikistan, Mayram is her family's sole means of support. She has come to us for a loan to expand her business and improve her family's income and living standard.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en: I am Nasreen S. from Lahore, a big metropolis in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of five, three boys and two girls. My husband operates a snack stall in a street near our house; we together prepare snacks for the stall. He has a lot of experience in his work and is a hard worker. He now wishes to expand his business and set up an additional snack stall. I am requesting a loan of $200 for him, so that he can buy the necessary items for his business expansion.  This way our monthly income will increase and we will be able to eat and clothe our family better.

loans.use: Expand her food stall

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.en: Muhabbat A. is one of  Microinvest’s most active clients, and over the last few years has proved to be an especially skillful, responsible and hard-working businesswoman. Her customers like doing business with her because she is very friendly and has a nice selection of items for sale. She has applied for a loan to increase the number and variety of goods available in her shop during the busy holiday season.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Sajida

texts.en:
I am Sajida B.. I was married when I was only 15. I am a mother of five children - two sons and three daughters. I have enrolled all of my children in school so that they can educate themselves and find better employment in the future. I learned stitching from my mother before I was married but could not practice it as a skill once I was married. This is because my husband did not want me to work. My husband runs a small spare parts business, which yields small profits.

My eldest son is now done with his studies and operates a motorcycle workshop. He not only repairs clients' bikes but also buys second hand bikes, repairs them and sells them at a good price. He now wishes to buy a few more second hand bikes for his business and requests a loan of $175.

loans.use: To expand her son's motorcycle repair business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Rano

texts.en: Rano T. lives with her husband and three children in the town of Spitamen. She is her family's sole means of support because all of her children are in school and her husband is unemployed, although he does help out at her shop. The market is unusually busy at this time of the year because of all the holiday shoppers, and Rano has applied for a loan to increase the selection of goods she has to sell. This increased selection will allow her to earn a substantially larger income at a time when her family needs it.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her tailoring business.

loans.name: Behruz Group

texts.en: Behruz is one of the most active client groups we have at Microinvest. Ahmad, the leader and person responsible for repaying the loan, is known locally for his kindness and willingness to help people who are going through difficulties. He and his colleagues sell candies and food such as cookies. Their business is doing very well, and operates in a great location with lots of foot traffic in the town food market.  They have applied for a loan to increase the supply of goods they have for sale during the busy New Year's holiday.

loans.use: Increasing the volume of sales in their shop

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena has a small business selling photograph accessories. She operates her business from a small outdoor sales kiosk at the Kahovski market in Kahovka, Ukraine. Because she has an outdoor location where she is unable to lock up her inventory, Elena sets up her product displays at the beginning of each day and packs everything up for storage at the end the day. Elena has been selling at the market for about five years. She started her own business after losing a factory job due to downsizing. Elena is married and has a three year old daughter and a twelve year old son. Her job is a good source of income for Elena and her husband, Nikolai, and allows her to take care of the family while Nikolai travels on business.

Elena has requested a loan of $1100 to add to her available capital so she can invest in her business and work on increasing her income.

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Matlyuba

texts.en: Matlyuba N. lives in the town of Spitamen, where she has worked in the local bazaar for the last eight years.  She is a very good saleswoman whose customers keep coming back to her shop because they like the quality of her products, the selection of goods she has to sell and the service she provides. Matlyuba has come to us for a loan which she will use to buy new items to sell and to attract new clients.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Ludmila

texts.en:
Ludmila makes a living as a market vendor, supporting herself with a small women’s clothing sales business in Kherson, Ukraine. Ludmila is divorced. She has two sons and lives with one of them in a tiny, 12 square meter apartment. Ludmila works many long hours at the Dnepr Rhinok, or market, where her business is located. She sells exclusive clothing with modern fashions that are good quality but reasonably priced. She is an experienced entrepreneur, having been in business for thirteen years.

Ludmila has requested a loan of $1000 to increase her inventory. This is Ludmila’s third loan from Nadiya Ukraine. She has proven to be a reliable client and we are happy for another opportunity to assist her with her business and livelihood.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is a small business owner from Kherson, Ukraine. She started her business about ten years ago because there were no other jobs available for her. Today, Tatyana has a little sales kiosk at the Dneprovski market in Kherson where she sells women’s clothing. Her kiosk is in a good location at the market which gives her a competitive edge in attracting passing customers. Tatyana is divorced and is raising a fifteen year old son. Her business provides valuable income for Tatyana to support herself and her son.

Tatyana has requested a loan of $1000 that will help her purchase new inventory and increase her profits. She has been an ideal loan client with Nadiya Ukraine and has benefited from the financial assistance that is available to her. We look forward to many more opportunities to help Tatyana run a successful, prosperous business.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Baroat

texts.en: Baroat A. is a 51-year-old woman with two children who lives in the town of Spitamen. After receiving her first loan in 2004, she proved herself to be an extremely capable and enthusiastic businesswoman who was able to find a solution to any problem. She also always makes her loan payments on time, which is why we are pleased that she has come to us for a new loan to once again expand her business and, with it, her income.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en: Dilorom A. sells children's clothes in the popular bazaar in her home town of Spitamen. She received her first loan from Microinvest earlier this year, and immediately proved herself to be an enthusiastic, hard-working and very responsible client. Her customers like doing business with her because she is an excellent saleswoman with an outstanding selection of goods. She has come to us for a new loan to expand the inventory of goods she has to sell in her shop.

loans.use: Increasing the assortment of goods for sale

loans.name: Zukhro

texts.en: Zukhro A. is divorced and has three children. Like mothers everywhere, her main goal in life is to help her children have a happy and successful future, and she is ready to work day and night to make that happen. This is not easy to do when you are a single mother, but Zukhro believes that she can reach her goal with a loan that will allow her to go into business selling rice, which is in high demand in her community. The people at Microinvest who know her also believe she can realize her dream because she is full of energy and enthusiasm, and because of her experience working at other small companies like the one she plans to open.

loans.use: To open a business that will help ensure her children's future

loans.name: Khalida

texts.en:
I am Khalida P. from Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. My husband and I both are scrap dealers. We operate a scrap store where we buy and sell old and used objects of various kinds. We have been doing this business for the last twelve years. The business generates just enough to put food on the table and send our children to school.
Our children are growing and so are our expenses. With every passing day, we feel the need to make extra income. Please lend me $350 to expand our scrap store. We will buy the scrap objects in bulk and will sell them to various other dealers.

loans.use: Expand scrap business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Khurshida

texts.en: I am a mother of six. I have four girls and two boys. My oldest son is done with his studies, and currently he is working. I sew clothes for my neighborhood clients to supplement my husband’s income. My husband is an electrician and he manufactures copper wires. Earlier, we took a loan and my husband invested it in his business.  The returns from this investment enabled us to repay the loan successfully and enroll two of our younger children in school.  Now, he is in the process of expanding his business and wants to buy copper in bulk. For this purpose, he needs a loan of $350.

loans.use: Buy copper in bulk

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Makhmadsaid

texts.en: Makhmadsaid Alovaddinov lives in J.Rasulovsky. He is married and has four children. From an early age he spent a lot of time working in the Dehkan farm. He has worked in the business sphere for over 10 years and has a good education. Currently, he is the holder of a private business which fattens heavy animals. Makhmadsaid is guided by the principle that  work should bring both pleasure and financial support.  He would like a loan to help purchase more livestock.

loans.use: livestock purchase

loans.name: Rukhsana

texts.en: I am a textile designer and I buy shawls and embed sequins on them. I started this business after my husband’s death in order to provide for my only daughter. She is in school in grade four. I am able to make $100 a month out of this business. Now I am in the process of expanding my business and want to buy shawls and sequins in bulk. For this purpose, I require a loan of $250. I will pool the extra profits in to my current business.

loans.use: To expand her shawl business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ugilkhon

texts.en: Ugilkhon A. is married and ives with her family in Spitamen. She has worked in the bazaar for five years. During her experience in materials sales, she has showed herself as capable of making new and profitable business. Her clients enjoy her expanding assortment of materials as her turnover is fast. She is seeking extra capital to expand her materials in order to satisfy customer demands, and to help improve her income.

loans.use: Business expansion and variety of goods

loans.name: Ugilkhon

texts.en: Ugilkhon A. is married and she lives with her family in Spitamen. She works in bazar 5 years and during her experience in materials' sale she showed herself as very capable of making business, she is quick and smart. They like her good assortment. Her turnover is fast and now she is seeking an extra capital for expanding her assortment of materials in order to satisfy customer demands and improve her income.

loans.use: Business expansion and variety of goods

loans.name: Nadia

texts.en: My name is Nadia B. and I have been married for two years. My husband works at a local gas station for scant pay whereas I make jackets on daily wages. I excel at my work but, I do not have enough funds to start a business of my own. If I am able to get $250 I will buy the necessary raw materials and will start my own jackets business. Please give me a loan. I hope the business will do well because winter is around the corner and the demand for jackets will increase sharply.

loans.use: Start her own jackets business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Abdukarim

texts.en: Abdukarim A. has been an active client of Microinvest since 2004.  Abdukarim lives in Mastchoh, Tajikstan and is married  with three children. The main direction of his private business are commercial sales in the bazaar  Having many interesting ideas for new business ventures requires a loan to support the future of his children, who would like to continue working  in the family business.

loans.use: to ensure the future of his children

loans.name: Mehreen

texts.en: I am Mehreen R. from Lahore, the second largest metropolis in Pakistan. I am married with four children - three girls and one boy. All of my children attend school. I mostly do household chores, but when I get time I sew clothes on order from my neighborhood clientele. My husband works at a garment factory. If he can buy an overlock sewing machine and get orders for overlocking clothes from his own factory, he will be able to double his income. Please lend us $250 for this purpose.

loans.use: Buy an overlock sewing machine

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ahmadjon

texts.en: Ahmadjon A. has been an active client of Microinvest since 2005.  Ahmadjon is married with three children. He implements the commercial services by holding the national “Oshkhona” in the bazaar. Ahmadjon is a very respectable family man and his family welfare is very important to him.  He requires a loan for a cow purchase to increase the selling of milk products.

loans.use: Cow purchase to increase the selling of milk products

loans.name: Mehri

texts.en: Mehri E. is mother of four children. She has a big family and with her children she sells fabrics the in Spitamen bazaar. She has been working in the bazaar 10 years and started with very little capital. She has worked in various other industries. Mehri sells fabric and has found this business is the most profitable for her family. She is applying for a  KIVA loan in order to increase her goods assortment.

loans.use: Fabric business expansion

loans.name: Oysuluv

texts.en: Oysuluv U. is an experienced seller, who has worked in the bazaar market for four years. This is the only source of income for her family. She has a stable business and her assets are increasing every month. She reimburses her loans in time without any problems. Her clients enjoy her attitude and are pleased by the goods she sells. Oysuluv wants to enlarge the assortment of goods for the New Year sale. She is secondly applies to KIVA for the urgent loan.

loans.use: Variety of goods

loans.name: Saidjon

texts.en: Saidjon A. lives in Mastchokh, is married and has four children. He is an active Microinvest client. His first appeal to Microinveat was in 2004 and the loan permanently increased his wealth. Keeping the commercial services Saidjon requires another loan to build a barn for 20-30 cows. He also runs a rather successful supplementary business in the flour selling industry, which only increases his growing business potential.

loans.use: Build a barn for 20-30 cows

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his shoe-selling business

loans.name: Abdukahor

texts.en: Abdukahor A. lives in Mastchokh, Tajikistan. He is married with children. Abdukahor works in the flour selling business. He applied to Microinvest for a loan for a vehicle purchase to help accelerate the business process.

loans.use: Vehicle purchase to accelerate process in flour selling business.

loans.name: Emmy

texts.en:
A new business for each new year? In 2006 Emmy K. established a business raising and selling guinea fowl. In January 2007 she added another, selling soft drinks and snacks (like the yummy cakes in the photo). She requires a loan of $525 to purchase additional soft drinks and ingredients like flour, sugar, and eggs in bulk, so that she can increase the quantity and range of her goods. Emmy has already successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA and we eagerly await any business proposals for 2008…

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback arrangement as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, and they are therefore termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional stock such as soft drinks and ingredients for her snacks

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Parviz

texts.en: Parviz is a single man who lives in Khachmaz region, in the village of Garagurtlu. This 24-year-old man has run this business for 4 years. Now he needs a loan of $475 to maintain his car for improving his business.

loans.use: To maintain his car

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
At 57, Annie Y. only recently ventured into the world of business but has so far been very successful. In 2006 she established a business raising and selling pigs. This year she added two other businesses, one raising and selling chickens (to keep the pigs company) and a small mushroom farm. Annie requires a loan of $700 for these two budding businesses. She plans to add more feathers and fungi. Annie is a mother of two and the profits from her businesses help support her daughter Secelela, 17, her niece Rachel, also 17, and her granddaughter Janeth, 9. Annie, the girls and all the livestock thank you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback arrangement as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, and they are therefore termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional chickens and farm inputs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 22, 2008)

texts.en:
This is Mama M.. She is 37 years old and married to Alphonsi with whom she has three children, Petro, 16, Edadi, 10 and Asante, 7. Aresia also cares for her niece, Upendo, 13 and her younger brother, Erici. She runs a business selling clothes and stationery and requires a loan of $275 to purchase additional stock and expand her business. She thanks you for your support. Happy lending!

loans.name: Zakariyya

texts.en: Married with  2 children, B.  lives in the village of Hadjilar in the Khachmaz region.  He has 8 years of experience in the dairy business. He wants to buy cows for getting more milk.  He plans to ferment milk and make cheese for sale. He needs a loan of $1200 to buy 2 cows.

loans.use: to buy 2 cows

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
“Mama Africa” is a favourite phrase of the locals here when they see a ‘mzungu’ (white person) wearing an African dress. Here is one of our suppliers, Nuru M.. She sells traditional (long, flowing and puffed-sleeved) and modern (tighter and sexier) African dresses of all styles and colours. She has operated the business since 2003 and requires a loan of $275 to purchase additional stock. She and her ten year-old daughter Hadija send their thanks.

loans.name: Sanubar

texts.en: Sanubar  and her 3 children  live in  the Khachmaz region. She sells bread in order to support her family. She needs a loan of $950 to buy foodstuffs to increase her business.

loans.use: to buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Flowing kaftans, tight-fitting fishtail skirts with matching tops, baby’s dresses, boys’ overalls, and evening dresses, all can be found at Justina’s clothing shop. She established the business in 2003 and requires a loan of $275 to expand it by purchasing additional stock. Justina is a single mother and the business helps her to support her three children, Mariam, 15, Amina, 11 and Julius, 3.

loans.name: Fagan

texts.en: Fagan is a  26 year old single man who lives in Khudat town. 10 years ago he started his cattle breeding  business. Now he needs a loan of  $600 to buy a calf  and fodder for increasing  the size his herd.

loans.use: to buy a calf

loans.name: Tasiana

texts.en:
At 34, Tasiana is already a seasoned businesswoman. In 1997 she opened a tailoring business and has now added a bustling little café in the small but busy town of Mbagala on the outskirts of Dar es Salaam, where she sells sodas and local food such as rice with beans, plaintain (a savoury banana) with meat, and ugali (the local maize staple), all served with a variety of delicious sauces.

Tasiana requires a loan for her café, so that she can buy inventory items and ingredients in bulk and thus maximise her profits. She cares for her two children, Neema, 9 and Linda, 4, as well as her nephew Musa (Moses), 17.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane’s "hotel" (aka pub) is a good place to chill with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. It’s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree, with a bad local beer in hand (sorry Tanzania), the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’ (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

Jane opened the business in 2005 and requires a loan of $425 to expand her business by purchasing some new furniture and additional stock (her happy customers have drunk the place dry!) Jane is an independent young woman with a ten year-old daughter, Harinet and she thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Eldar

texts.en: Eldar lives in Khachmaz region. He is single and 41 years old. He has been as a joiner for 12 years. He buys the materials and makes doors and windows in his shop. Now he needs a loan of $725 to buy necessary materials for making doors and windows.

loans.use: to buy necessary materials for making doors and windows

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
This is Mama Tukae. She is 32 years old and married to husband Abdallah with whom she has three children, Tukae (hence her nickname), 12, Khalfani, 9, and Yasini, 5, as well as her nephew Ramadhani, 15, in her care. She runs a farm in the rural town of Kibamba, on the road from Dar es Salaam to Arusha in Tanzania. She grows maize and sorghum (a cereal/grain crop) and raises goats (which she beats if they venture too near the crops!)

Mama Tukae requires a loan of $350 to purchase farming equipment, seeds, and some more goats--maybe some cute baby ones that won’t be as stubborn as her current herd!

loans.name: Vailety

texts.en:
This is 27-year-old Vailety, who runs a funky clothes shop in Kinondoni, ten minutes from downtown Dar es Salaam. This is one of the real hubs of Dar, a place where you walk down the main street and see the latest street fashion and mobile phone shops, along with truck stations and hole-in-the-wall eateries, all the while listening simultaneously to hip-hop music blasting from who-knows-where and haunting chants from the mosques calling people to prayer.

Vailety started the business in 2005 and requires a loan of US$ 700 to purchase additional stock. The business supports her and her one-year-old son Daudi (David).

loans.name: Matrida

texts.en:
In the rural town of Tanita, Matrida L. (commonly and affectionately known as Mama L.) sells milk, vegetables and soap. The vegetables were a new addition in 2006 but it is her original milk-selling business, established in 2001, into which Mama L. wants to inject some new capital. She wants to revitalise the business by increasing her stock and purchasing a wider range of types and brands.

Mama L. is married to husband Felix and has three children, Franki, 18, Godwini, 17, and Dicsoni, 15. She hopes to increase her profits so that she can continue to support her family.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
In the busy town of Kibaha Kwa Matias, Fatuma M. runs a busy little eatery popular amongst locals, who pop in for a lunch of rice, beans, ugali (maize porridge), cassava, vegetables, meat and soda. Fatuma established the business in 2003 and has since successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA. She now requires a loan of $525 to purchase new utensils and inventory for the café.

Fatuma is a single mother of two, Chande, 16, and Happy, 14, and her business enables her to support her family. She thanks you for your help as she works toward expanding her business turnover.

loans.name: Khatira

texts.en: Khatira is 45 years old. She is married, has 5 children and lives in Khachmaz town. She started her business five years ago selling glassware and dressing gowns at retail.  She needs a loan of $950 to buy glassware, dressing gowns and bathrobes to increase her business.

loans.use: To buy a lot of glassware, dressing gown and bathrobe

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Karibu (welcome!) to 24-year-old Judith, who plans to open her own hair and beauty salon, where she will weave, cut, plait and paint! To make her dream a reality, Judith requires a start-up loan of $425 to be repaid within 12 months. She plans to use the loan to buy equipment such as dryers, as well as a stock of hair products such as shampoo, conditioner, and styling gel. She is a high-school graduate and is confident that the skills she gained will enable her to make a success of her as-yet-unnamed salon.

loans.name: Radhia

texts.en:
2007 was a year of new ventures and big business for Radhia M.! She set an (unofficial) SELFINA record and opened four businesses; a general store, a fruit and vegetable stall, a small chicken farm, and a roadside charcoal stand. Radhia requires a loan of $350 to expand the general store and the fruit and vegetable stall by purchasing additional stock and produce. She is married to husband Salehe and has one child, Setembo, 3.

loans.name: Ulyana

texts.en:
Ulyana is single. She runs her own business selling groceries from a small food store in the town of Kavskye in the Stryi region of western Ukraine. Her little store is well known in their town for friendly customer service and reasonable prices. Ulyana started her venture with the help of her parents and has been in this business for 1 year. Despite her relatively recent start, she already has about $6000 in inventory. Her monthly net profit is about $400.  

Ulyana is requesting a loan of $800 to remodel her store. She is hoping to continue growing her business and open a second store in the near future. Ulyana has a kind heart. She supports the local church financially and serves the needy in her community. She has a very good reputation in the town. We believe her focused work, enthusiasm and spirit of initiative will help her succeed and repay her loan on time.

loans.use: To purchase construction supplies and remodel her grocery store

loans.name: Agnesi

texts.en:
This is Agnesi M.. She is 37 years old and married to husband Ositari, with whom she has two children, Isaka, 19 and Raheli, 10. She owns a kiosk selling various small items in the rural town of Boko Mnemeia, 30km outside of Dar es Salaam. Agnes is requesting a loan of $425 which she will use to increase the quantity and range of her stock, with the aim of increasing her modest monthly earnings of approximately $50.

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
The image of an African woman carrying a load on her head has become a somewhat stereotypical symbol of the burdens borne by women in Africa. But it truly does represent the strength and resilience of our sisters on the hot continent, whose determination to create opportunities where there are none, and to provide for themselves and their families is inspiring.

Asia is one such hawker who roams the streets (where there are streets!) and compounds of her neighbours in the rural town of Tumbi, approximately 30km outside Dar es Salaam. She sells all kinds of things, from fruit and vegetables to soap, toothpaste and phone credit. Asia requires a loan of $525 to purchase additional stock, which she will undoubtedly manage to fit in her huge basin, and more incredibly, manage to carry on her head! She is married to husband and Raphael with whom she has two children, Fredrick, 16 and Kheri, 13.

In the rural town of Mkoani, Lilian M. brings a touch of modern style. SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback arrangement as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, and they are therefore termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional clothing and shoes for re-sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Annath

texts.en:
Across the oceans from America and Europe travel second-hand clothes, which are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to people like Anath who then takes them back to her village of Yombo Kilakala where she re-washes and re-irons them for sale to her neighbours and other customers. Anath has been engaged in this business since 2003 and currently requires a loan of $425 to travel to Dar es Salaam and replenish her stock. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through a leasing and leaseback arrangement as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, and they are therefore termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of second-hand clothing for re-sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Gulkhanim

texts.en: Gulkhanim (her husband is pictured)  is 46 years old and has 2 children. She and her family live in Khachmaz town.  This family has sold the building materials for 10 years. Now they need a loan of $850  to buy building materials for improving their business.

loans.use: to buy building materials

loans.name: Libana

texts.en:
Libana belongs to the La Familia (The Family) Communal Bank. She lives on the 3,800 kilometer of Centenario Avenue in the district of Calleria in Ucayali. She is 59-years-old and is the mother of 3 children who are now adults. They help her with her business when they can. She used to sell candy, but the income she maD. doesn't cover all of the family expenses. This is why Libana used the first loan that she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 nuevos soles ($100) to invest in selling soft drinks, both wholesale and retail.

Presently she has a store where she sells soft drinks, which is located in her home. She also prepares sandwiches. She gets up very early to prepare breakfast and then dedicates herself to her business all day. She also has the support of her husband and kids. In her free time, she likes to read and knit.

With the current loan received from Manuela Ramos of 2,000 nuevos soles ($669), which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy 20 boxes and packages of large and small soft drinks, a dozen sausages, and 6 packages of candy (at wholesale prices).

Libana is very peaceful thanks to Manuela Ramos because they knew how to advise her so she could start her business and have economic stability, which lets her be happy at the siD. of her loved ones.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Libana pertenece al Banco Comunal La Familia, vive en la Av. Centenario Km. 3.800, del distrito Calleria, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 59 años D. edad y es madre D. 3 hijos que ya son mayores D. edad, pero cuando pueden la apoyan en su negocio, su esposo se dedica a la venta D. golosinas, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos familiares, es así que Libana, con el primer préstamo que recibió D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) deciD. invertirlo en la venta D. gaseosas al por mayor y menor.

En la actualidad cuenta con una tienda D. venta D. bebidas gaseosas, ubicada en su misma casa; paralelamente prepara samwich (alimentos), se levanta muy temprano para preparar el desayuno para después dedicarse a su negocio todo el día. Cuenta con la ayuda D. su esposo y sus hijos. En sus ratos libres le gusta mucho leer y tejer.

Con el actual préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 2,000 (US$ 669.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 20 cajas y paquetes D. gaseosas grandes y chicas, pan, una docena D. salchichas y 6 paquetes D. golosinas (al por mayor).

Libana, está muy tranquila gracias a Manuela Ramos, porque supieron orientarla para que ella pueda poner su negocio y así tener una estabilidad económica, la cual le permite estar feliz a lado D. sus seres más queridos.

loans.use: Purchase of soft drinks at wholesale prices, purchase of candy.

loans.name: María Bertola

texts.es:
María belongs to the Las Esmeraldas Communal Bank, AA. HH. San Juan Ucayali Pasaje José Balta S/N, Calleria District, Ucayali state. She is 62 years old and is mother to 11 children. Her husband is a farmer, but the income doesn't meet the household expenses, so María, with the first loan from Manuela Ramos for 300 Soles (US $100.00), decided to invest in beauty products.

To date, her beauty product sales and customers have increased, and now she sells various well-known brands of beauty products. She gets up very early to do her household chores, then she dedicates herself to selling products. She sells to customers house to house and also from her home.

With the recent loan from Manuela Ramos for 1,500 Soles (approximately US $502.00), which will be repaid in 5 months, she will buy a large quantity of beauty products (500 Soles in 5 fragrances, 8 powders, 5 lotions, 10 deoderants, 15 creams, 4 shampoos, etc.), all of which will help her have a good supply of stock.

María is very happy to have her 11 healthy children and to have achieved that they have finished their studies. The older children now have their own families but she still has to educate the youngest children.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Maria, pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Esmeraldas, AA. HH. San Juan Ucayali Pasaje José Balta S/N, del Distrito de Calleria del departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 62 años y es madre de 11 hijos, su esposo es agricultor, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos del hogar, es así que María, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decide invertir en productos de belleza.

A la fecha, la venta de productos de belleza ha incrementado así como su clientela, ahora vende productos de belleza de varias marcas conocidas, se levanta muy temprano para atender las labores de la casa, luego de ello se dedica a la venta de sus productos. La venta la realiza casa por casa pero también atiende a sus clientes en su propio domicilio.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,500 (US$ 502.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará mayor cantidad de productos de belleza (S/. 500.00 en 5 fragancias, 8 talcos, 5 lociones, 10 desodorantes, 15 cremas, 4 champúes, etc.), todo esto le servirá para contar con un buen stock.

María está muy contenta de tener a sus 11 hijos sanos y haber logrado que terminen sus estudios. Los mayores ya tienen familia pero aun falta educar a los más pequeños.

loans.use: Purchase beauty products (cosmetics and perfumes)

loans.name: Vugar

texts.en: Vugar is a 26 year old single man who lives in Khachmaz town. He and his brother (pictured) have been in  business for a year. They buy sheep to fatten for sale in market. Now they need a loan of  $850 to buy 10 sheep.

loans.use: to buy 10 sheep

loans.name: Melina

texts.es:
Melina belongs to the La Familia (The Family) communal bank and lives in the Calleria district of Ucayali. She is 67 years old and the mother of three adult children who are already professionals. They are the priD. of their mother and do not forget the great sacrifices she maD. to always proviD. them with the best. Melina is married, her husband works in the Triplayera Amazónico (a wood factory), but his income is not sufficient for the expenses of their home. That is how Melina decided, with the first loan from Manuela Ramos of S/. 300 (US $100), to invest in the sale of prepared meals.

In actuality, she wakes very early to prepare breakfast, then goes to the market to buy the necessary ingredients for the preparation of her meals. In the afternoon, she distributes meals to her clients who wait for her anxiously since her food has an enviable and well-liked flavor.

With this loan from Manuela Ramos for 1,500 nuevos soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will invest in the purchase of 4 cases of soda pop, 4 cases of beer, 16 little wooden stools, tablecloths and one dozen plates. This will be used to start a small restaurant that offers typical regional dishes.

Melina, despite her age, still has lots of energy and the will to progress. Her biggest dream is to one day own a chain of restaurants offering her regional dishes, and that everyone can enjoy her delicious flavoring as she pleases her clients’ palates. She hopes to achieve this thanks to the support of Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Melina pertenece al banco comunal La Familia, vive en el Jr. Alfredo Eglinton Mz C Lt 1, del distrito D. Calleria del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 67 años y es madre D. 3 hijos mayores D. edad que ya son profesionales. Ellos son el orgullo D. su madre y no olvidan el gran sacrificio que hizo ella por siempre darles lo mejor. La señora Melina está casada, su esposo trabaja en la Triplayera Amazónico (maderera), pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos del hogar, es así que Melina, con el primer préstamo D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300.00 (US$100.00) deciD. invertir en la venta y preparación D. comidas.

En la actualidad ella se levanta muy temprano para preparar el desayuno, irse al mercado y comprar los insumos que necesita para la preparación D. sus comidas. En las tardes se alista y sale a repartir sus comidas a sus clientes que con ansias la esperan, por que doña Melina tiene una sazón envidiable y que gusta mucho.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 1,500, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, invertirá en la compra D. 4 cajas D. gaseosas, 4 caja D. cervezas, 16 banquitos D. madera, manteles y 1 docena D. platos, esto le servirá para instalar un pequeño restaurante D. comida típica D. la región.

Melina, a pesar D. su edad, tiene aun mucha energía y ganas D. querer salir adelante y su sueño mas granD. es tener una cadena D. restaurantes D. comidas típicas en la región y que todos puedan disfrutar D. su deliciosa sazón y engalanar el paladar D. sus clientes. Espera lograrlo gracias al apoyo D. Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Purchase capital to open a small restaurant.

loans.name: Ramin

texts.en: Ramin is 25 years old and single.  He lives in Khudat town. He has been running this business  for 3 years. He is requesting a loan of $850 to buy spare parts for his car because he has a lot of problems with his car. He wants to repair  his car and to support his clients with good service.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Mirna Enith

texts.es:
Mirna belongs to a community bank called La Familia. She lives in Asentamiento Humano Juanita Alcántara C 11, in the district of Calleria within the state of Ucayali. She is married, 50 years old, and a mother of 3 who are still dependent on her. She is a primary school teacher and a wife of a chauffeur, but their income is insufficient to meet their living costs. This is the reason Mirna decided to invest in timber with the first loan of $100 she received from Manuela Ramos. This was in association with her son-in-law.

Currently, her timber sales have increased due to the demand for this resource in the large region she resides. Every morning, Mirna wakes up early to make breakfast and brings her children and grandchildren to school. She is very happy.

The next loan will be paid back in 4 months. She will buy 2 cylinders of fuel to transport her timber. One-third of the loan (S/. 600) will be used for transport costs. She will also buy 1 power saw and the rest will be invested in various timber (Quinilla, Cedar, and a bit of mahogany).

Mirna is very grateful to Manuela Ramos since it has been the means for the loan to be granted to her. She was enabled to develop her timber business and tend to other things that she could not: move her timber and sell them.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Mirna pertenece al banco comunal La Familia, vive en el Asentamiento Humano Juanita Alcántara C 11, del Distrito de Calleria del departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 50 años y es madre de 3 hijos que aun dependen de ella, está casada. Es profesora de primaria y su esposo es chofer, pero el ingreso que tienen no alcanza para los gastos del hogar, es así que Mirna, con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 (US$ 100.00) decidió invertir en el negocio de la madera, esto en asociación con su yerno.

En la actualidad, su negocio de compra y venta de madera ha aumentado debido a la demanda de ese recurso en nuestra región, ya que nuestra ubicación geográfica es muy grande. La señora Mirna se levanta temprano para hacer el desayuno y después lleva a sus hijos y algunos nietos a la escuela, esto la hace muy feliz.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,800, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 2 cilindros de combustible para transportar su madera, pagará S/. 600.00 en transporte, comprará 1 motosierra, y el resto lo invertirá en madera (Quinilla, Cedro y un poco de Caoba).

Mirna está muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos, ya que por medio del préstamo que le dieron, ella pudo aumentar la compra de madera, así mismo de algunas cosas que le hacían falta para poder trasladar su madera y venderla acá.

loans.use: Buy fuel, one power saw, and timber

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Re-stocking corn (maize)

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa belongs to the community bank "Teresa Ramos" and lives in the district of Yarina Cocha, department of Ucayali. She is 41 years old and the mother of 2 children, one who goes to university and the other who is of legal age. She is married and her husband sells lubricants. His income was not enough to cover their household expenses so Rosa, with her first loan from Manuela Ramos, decided to put a small restaurant in her home.

She currently opens the restaurant only for breakfast and lunch; at night she rests up for the following day´s tasks. She starts her activities at 4:00 in the morning while, at the same time, she takes care of her children.

With a loan from Manuela Ramos, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy 3 kilos of rice, 1 kilo of sugar, vegetables, 2 sets of dishes, and a dozen spoons. In addition, she will also invest in maintenance of the kitchen, which needs repair. She will also expand and improve her establishment, for which she will need 5 sacks of cement, 4 meters of rubble, and 5 iron rods.

Rosa is very content because she sees that more and more people come to her restaurant. This gives her greater desire to get ahead in her business, which allows her to cover the expenses of her daughter´s university studies.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Rosa pertenece al Banco Comunal “Teresa Ramos”, vive en Jr. Ruperto Pérez S/N, del distrito de Yarina Cocha del departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 41 años y es madre de 2 hijos, uno de ellos esta en la universidad y el otro es mayor de edad. Está casada, su esposo se dedica a la venta de lubricantes, pero el ingreso que tiene no les alcanza para los gastos del hogar, es así que Rosa, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos, decide poner un pequeño restaurante en su misma casa.

En la actualidad atiende en su restaurante solo con desayunos y almuerzos, ya que en la noche descansa temprano para la faena del día siguiente. Inicia sus actividades a partir de las 4.00 de la mañana, paralelamente atiende a sus hijos.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 3 kilos de arroz, 1 kilo de azucar, S/. 50.00 de verduras, 2 juegos de Platos, 1 docena de cucharas. Además invertirá en el mantenimiento de su cocina la cual necesita reparacipon. También ampliará y mejorara su establecimiento, para ello necesitará 5 bolsas de cemento, 4 metros de ripio y 5 varillas de fierro.

Rosa esta muy contenta porque ve que su restaurante es cada vez mas concurrido, esto le da mayores ganas de salir adelante en su negocio, el cual le permite cubrir los gastos de los estudios universitarios de su hija.

loans.use: Purchase of food supplies and kitchen utensils. Repair and maintenance of commercial premises.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
Mrs. Sonia belongs to the communal bank “Las Fresitas.” She lives at Jr. Iparia Mz. 35 Lot 8 in the city of Yarina Cocha in the state of Ucayali, Peru. She is 49 years old and the mother of 3 adult children. They are very appreciative of all the effort she has made to ensure that they never went without and are very proud of her. Mrs. Sonia is married and her husband is a chauffer. His income, however, is not enough to cover the family’s living expenses. With her first loan borrowed from Manuela Ramos in the amount of 300 ‘soles’ ($ 100) she decided to invest in the sale of used clothes to the homes surrounding the Ucayali River, much like she has already been doing. Her business is currently growing due to high demand for used clothes. She wakes up very early to complete her household duties and then goes out to purchase the merchandise she will later sell. She visits the area surrounding the Ucayali River weekly to sell her merchandise. Mrs. Sonia has recently requested a loan from Manuela Ramos in the amount of 2,000 ‘soles’ (approx. $669), which will be repaid within 6 months, she plans to purchase 2 bales of clothes, 30 pairs of shoes and 10 pairs of slippers, along with other articles of clothing per personal use. Sonia is very happy to have her children healthy and professionals. They are her pride and joy. Thanks her efforts and dedication, she is achieving all her desires.

Translated from Spanish by Christian Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Sonia pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Fresitas”, vive en el Jr. Iparia Mz. 35 Lt. 8, distrito de Yarina Cocha D. departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 49 años y es madre de 3 hijos, todos mayores de edad. Están muy agradecidos con ella por todo el esfuerzo que hizo para nunca hacerles faltar nada y están orgullosos de ella. La señora Sonia está casada, su esposo es chofer, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para cubrir los gastos D. hogar. Con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 (US$ 100.00) decide invertir en la venta de ropa usada, la misma que lleva a vender por los caseríos aledaños al rió Ucayali. En la actualidad su negocio ha crecido debido a la gran demanda de sus clientes. Se levanta muy temprano para hacer los quehaceres de la casa y de ahí sale a comprar las prendas de vestir que llevará a vender. Ella realiza sus viajes semanalmente. Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 2,000 (US$ 669.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará 2 fardos de ropas, 30 pares de zapatos y 10 pares de zapatillas, así como otros productos de uso personal. Sonia se siente muy contenta de tener a sus 3 hijos sanos y profesionales, ellos son su orgullo. Gracias a su esfuerzo y dedicación, está cumpliendo todos sus anhelos.

loans.use:
Purchase of used clothing in bulk. Purchase of shoes and other products of personal use.

Compra de ropa usada al por mayor. Compra de calzado y otros productos de uso personal.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
Sonia belongs to the communal bank Mujeres Virtuosas (Virtuous Women). She lives on 578 San Fernando Avenue in the Manantay district in Ucayali. She is 56-years-old and is the mother of four children. Her husband is a merchant, but his income isn't enough to cover all of their home's expenses. This is why Sonia, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 nuevos soles ($100), decided to start a small business of buying and selling used clothing in her home.

Currently, Sonia has a store where she buys and sells used clothes and shoes for women, men, and children. It's going well for her without any problems. Thanks to her earnings, she has enough to pay the installments of her loan in a punctual manner.

With the recent loan she received from Manuela Ramos of 2,000 nuevos soles ($669), which will be repaid in 6 months, she bought more second-hand clothing, 30 shoes, 10 wallets, 3 mannequins, 2 sales counters, and 30 hangers. Sonia feels very happy with the work that she does because she puts in a lot of affection and persistence to accomplish her goals. Thanks to this business, she can offer her family and herself economic stability.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Sonia pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Virtuosas, vive en Av. San Fernando 578, del distrito D. Manantay del departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 56 años y es madre D. 4 hijos, su esposo es comerciante, pero sus ingresos no alcanza para solventar los gastos del hogar, es así que Sonia, con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300.00 (US$100.00) deciD. poner un pequeño negocio D. compra y venta D. ropa usada, en su propio domicilio ubicado en el distrito D. Manantay.

En la actualidad, Sonia tiene una tienda D. compra y venta D. ropa y zapatos usados, para damas, caballeros y niños. Le va muy bien y sin ningún inconveniente. Gracias a sus ingresos tiene lo suficiente para pagar las cuotas del préstamo en forma puntual.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 2,000 (US$ 669.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 6 meses, compró mas ropa D. segunda mano, 30 zapatos, 10 carteras, 3 maniquíes, 2 mostradores y 30 colgadores.

Sonia se siente muy feliz con el trabajo que realiza, por lo que le pone mucho cariño y empeño para lograr sus objetivos y metas trazadas. Gracias a este negocio brinda a su familia y así misma estabilidad económica.

loans.use: Purchase of wholesale used clothes, footwear, mannequins, and a sales counter

loans.name: Aan

texts.en: Aan is 40 years old and has a 12 year old child. She sells vegetables using her  motorcycle for transportation. She can earn US$10 per day. In the  evenings, her husband A. earns more money transporting people on his motorcycle and usually earns US$2 per day. She needs a loan to expand her business and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Yati
